   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

    </div>

      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the European country. For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Norway_(disambiguation)" title="Norway (disambiguation)">
        Norway (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .

        <th class="adr" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding:0.25em 0.33em 0.33em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:1.25em;">
         <span class="fn org country-name">
          Kingdom of Norway
         </span>
         <br/>
         <div style="padding-top:0.25em;">
          <div class="plainlist">
           <ul>
            <li style="font-size:80%;">
             <i>
              <span lang="nb">
               <i>
                Kongeriket Norge
               </i>
              </span>
             </i>
             <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">
              (
              <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Bokm%C3%A5l_language" title="Norwegian Bokmål language">
               Norwegian Bokmål
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </li>

             <i>
              <span lang="nn">
               <i>
                Kongeriket Noreg
               </i>
              </span>
             </i>

              (
              <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Nynorsk_language" title="Norwegian Nynorsk language">
               Norwegian Nynorsk
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </li>
            <li style="font-size:80%;">
             <i>
              <span lang="se">
               <i>
                Norgga gonagasriika
               </i>
              </span>
             </i>
             <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">
              (
              <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Sami_language" title="Northern Sami language">
               Northern Sami
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>

        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
          <b>
           Motto:
          </b>
          <br/>
          <i>
           <span lang="no">
            <i>
             Enig og tro til Dovre faller
             <br/>
             (
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norway_in_1814" title="Norway in 1814">
              Eidsvoll oath
             </a>
             )
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">
            Norwegian
           </a>
           )
          </span>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="anthem" colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
          <b>
           Anthem:
          </b>
          <div class="plainlist">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <i>
              <a href="/wiki/Ja,_vi_elsker_dette_landet" title="Ja, vi elsker dette landet">

              </a>
             </i>

             </span>
             <small>
              (
              <i>
               <a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">
                de facto
               </a>
              </i>
              )
             </small>
            </li>
            <li>
             (English:
             <span lang="en">

             </span>
             )
            </li>

         </a>

          </a>

          </a>

          </a>

       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Capital
         <br/>
         <span style="font-weight:normal">
          and largest city
         </span>
        </th>
        <td>

         <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time" title="Central European Summer Time">
          CEST
         </a>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">
          UTC
         </a>
         +2)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Date format
        </th>
        <td>
         dd.mm.yyyy
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right-_and_left-hand_traffic" title="Right- and left-hand traffic">
          Drives on the
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         right
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Norway" title="Telephone numbers in Norway">
          Calling code
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Norway" title="Telephone numbers in Norway">
          +47
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">
          ISO 3166 code
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:NO" title="ISO 3166-2:NO">
          NO
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">
          Internet TLD
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/.no" title=".no">
          .no
         </a>
         <sup>
          c
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
          <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em; font-size:90%;">
           <li value="1">
            Does not include
            <a href="/wiki/Svalbard_and_Jan_Mayen" title="Svalbard and Jan Mayen">
             Svalbard and Jan Mayen
            </a>
            . (With the territories, it is the 61st largest country at 385,178 square kilometers)
           </li>
           <li value="2">
            This percentage is for the mainland, Svalbard, and Jan Mayen. This percentage counts glaciers as "land". It's calculated as 19,940.14/(365,246.17+19,940.14).
            <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
             [
             <i>
              <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
               <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2018)">
                citation needed
               </span>
              </a>
             </i>
             ]
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li value="3">
            Two more TLDs have been assigned, but are not used:
            <a href="/wiki/.sj" title=".sj">
             .sj
            </a>
            for Svalbard and Jan Mayen;
            <a href="/wiki/.bv" title=".bv">
             .bv
            </a>
            for
            <a href="/wiki/Bouvet_Island" title="Bouvet Island">
             Bouvet Island
            </a>
            .
           </li>
          </ol>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Norway
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/ɔːr/: 'ar' in 'war'">
            ɔːr
           </span>
           <span title="'w' in 'wind'">
            w
           </span>
           <span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">
            eɪ
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Norway.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fb/En-us-Norway.ogg" title="En-us-Norway.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key">
        <i title="English pronunciation respelling">
         <span style="font-size:90%">
          NAWR
         </span>
         -way
        </i>
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">
        Norwegian
       </a>
       :
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Norge_(country).ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/22/No-Norge.oga" title="No-Norge.oga">
          <i>
           Norge
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Bokm%C3%A5l" title="Bokmål">
        Bokmål
       </a>
       ) or
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:No-Noreg.oga" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e9/No-Noreg.oga" title="No-Noreg.oga">
          <i>
           Noreg
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Nynorsk" title="Nynorsk">
        Nynorsk
       </a>
       );
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Sami_language" title="Northern Sami language">
        Northern Sami
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="se">
         Norga
        </span>
       </i>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Kingdom of Norway
       </b>
       , is a
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">
        sovereign state
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Monarchy" title="Monarchy">
        monarchy
       </a>
       whose territory comprises the western portion of the
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Peninsula" title="Scandinavian Peninsula">
        Scandinavian Peninsula
       </a>
       plus the remote island of
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Mayen" title="Jan Mayen">
        Jan Mayen
       </a>
       and the archipelago of
       <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
        Svalbard
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [note 1]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Antarctic
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_I_Island" title="Peter I Island">
        Peter I Island
       </a>
       and the sub-Antarctic
       <a href="/wiki/Bouvet_Island" title="Bouvet Island">
        Bouvet Island
       </a>
       are
       <a href="/wiki/Dependencies_of_Norway" title="Dependencies of Norway">
        dependent territories
       </a>
       and thus not considered part of the Kingdom. Norway also lays claim to a section of
       <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">
        Antarctica
       </a>
       known as
       <a href="/wiki/Queen_Maud_Land" title="Queen Maud Land">
        Queen Maud Land
       </a>
       . Until 1814, the kingdom included the
       <a href="/wiki/Faroe_Islands" title="Faroe Islands">
        Faroe Islands
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">
        Greenland
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       . It also included
       <a href="/wiki/Bohusl%C3%A4n" title="Bohuslän">
        Bohuslän
       </a>
       until 1658,
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A4mtland" title="Jämtland">
        Jämtland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A4rjedalen" title="Härjedalen">
        Härjedalen
       </a>
       until 1645,
       <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">
        Shetland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">
        Orkney
       </a>
       until 1468, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">
        Hebrides
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">
        Isle of Man
       </a>
       until 1266.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway has a total area of 385,252 square kilometres (148,747 sq mi) and a population of 5,258,317 (as of January 2017).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Population-13">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country shares a long eastern border with
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_land_borders" title="List of countries and territories by land borders">
        1,619 km
       </a>
       or 1,006 mi long). Norway is bordered by
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       to the north-east, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Skagerrak" title="Skagerrak">
        Skagerrak
       </a>
       strait to the south, with
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       on the other side. Norway has an extensive coastline, facing the North Atlantic Ocean and the
       <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">
        Barents Sea
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Harald_V" title="King Harald V">
        King Harald V
       </a>
       of the Dano-German
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Gl%C3%BCcksburg" title="House of Glücksburg">
        House of Glücksburg
       </a>
       is the current
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Norway" title="King of Norway">
        King of Norway
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Erna_Solberg" title="Erna Solberg">
        Erna Solberg
       </a>
       became Prime Minister in 2013, and was reelected in September, 2017. Erna Solberg replaced
       <a href="/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg" title="Jens Stoltenberg">
        Jens Stoltenberg
       </a>
       who was the Prime Minister between 2000-2001 and 2005-2013. A
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
        constitutional monarchy
       </a>
       , Norway
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Separation_of_power" title="Separation of power">
        divides state power
       </a>
       between the
       <a href="/wiki/Storting" title="Storting">
        Parliament
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Norway" title="Cabinet of Norway">
        Cabinet
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Norway" title="Supreme Court of Norway">
        Supreme Court
       </a>
       , as determined by the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Norway" title="Constitution of Norway">
        1814 Constitution
       </a>
       . The kingdom was established as a merger of a large number of
       <a href="/wiki/Petty_kingdoms_of_Norway" title="Petty kingdoms of Norway">
        petty kingdoms
       </a>
       . By the traditional count from the year
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hafrsfjord" title="Battle of Hafrsfjord">
        872
       </a>
       , the kingdom has existed continuously for 1,145 years, and the list of Norwegian monarchs includes over sixty kings and earls.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway has both administrative and political subdivisions on two levels:
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Norway" title="Counties of Norway">
        counties
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Norway" title="List of municipalities of Norway">
        municipalities
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A1mi_people" title="Sámi people">
        Sámi people
       </a>
       have a certain amount of self-determination and influence over traditional territories through the
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_Parliament_of_Norway" title="Sami Parliament of Norway">
        Sámi Parliament
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Finnmark_Act" title="Finnmark Act">
        Finnmark Act
       </a>
       . Norway
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norway_%E2%80%93_European_Union_relations" title="Norway – European Union relations">
        maintains close ties
       </a>
       with both the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        United States
       </a>
       . Norway is a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">
        European Free Trade Association
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_System" title="Antarctic Treaty System">
        Antarctic Treaty
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council" title="Nordic Council">
        Nordic Council
       </a>
       ; a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">
        European Economic Area
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        WTO
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       ; and a part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">
        Schengen Area
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The country maintains a combination of
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       and a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nordic_welfare_model" title="Nordic welfare model">
        Nordic welfare model
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
        universal health care
       </a>
       and a comprehensive
       <a href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">
        social security
       </a>
       system. Norway has extensive reserves of
       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
        petroleum
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
        natural gas
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minerals" title="Minerals">
        minerals
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lumber" title="Lumber">
        lumber
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Seafood" title="Seafood">
        seafood
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">
        fresh water
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">
        hydropower
       </a>
       . The petroleum industry accounts for around a quarter of the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        gross domestic product
       </a>
       (GDP).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On a
       <a href="/wiki/Per_capita" title="Per capita">
        per-capita
       </a>
       basis, Norway is the world's largest producer of oil and natural gas outside the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
        Middle East
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The country has the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">
        fourth-highest
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">
        per capita income
       </a>
       in the world on the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">
        IMF
       </a>
       lists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">
        CIA
       </a>
       's GDP (PPP) per capita list (2015 estimate) which includes autonomous territories and regions, Norway ranks as number eleven.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has the world's largest
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund" title="Sovereign wealth fund">
        sovereign wealth fund
       </a>
       , with a value of USD 1 trillion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway has had the highest
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       ranking in the world since 2009, a position also held previously between 2001 and 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_20-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It also has the highest inequality-adjusted ranking.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI2_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HDI2-21">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway ranks first on the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Happiness_Report" title="World Happiness Report">
        World Happiness Report
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/OECD_Better_Life_Index" title="OECD Better Life Index">
        OECD Better Life Index
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Integrity" title="Global Integrity">
        Index of Public Integrity
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">
        Democracy Index
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

        </h2>
       </div>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2">
         <a href="#History">
          <span class="tocnumber">

          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           History
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3">
           <a href="#Prehistory">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Prehistory
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4">
           <a href="#Bronze_Age">

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5">

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Migration period
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7">

            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Viking Age
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8">
           <a href="#Kalmar_Union">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.6
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Kalmar Union
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9">
           <a href="#Union_with_Denmark">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.7
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Union with Denmark
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10">
           <a href="#Union_with_Sweden">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.8
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Union with Sweden
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11">
           <a href="#Dissolution_of_the_union">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.9
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Dissolution of the union
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-12">

        </li>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ohthere.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="161" data-file-width="677" height="78" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ohthere.jpg/330px-Ohthere.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ohthere.jpg/495px-Ohthere.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ohthere.jpg/660px-Ohthere.jpg 2x" width="330"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ohthere.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Opening of
         <a href="/wiki/Ohthere_of_H%C3%A5logaland" title="Ohthere of Hålogaland">
          Ohthere's
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_English_language" title="Old English language">
          Old English
         </a>
         account, translated: "Ohthere told his lord
         <i>
          Ælfrede
         </i>
         king that he lived northmost of all
         <span class="nowrap">
          Norwegians…"
         </span>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway has two official names:
       <i>
        Norge
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Bokm%C3%A5l" title="Bokmål">
        Bokmål
       </a>
       and
       <i>
        Noreg
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Nynorsk" title="Nynorsk">
        Nynorsk
       </a>
       . The English name Norway comes from the
       <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">
        Old English
       </a>
       word
       <i>
        Norþweg
       </i>
       mentioned in 880, meaning "northern way" or "way leading to the north", which is how the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon" title="Anglo-Saxon">
        Anglo-Saxons
       </a>
       referred to the coastline of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atlantic" title="Atlantic">
        atlantic
       </a>
       Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nomino-NRK_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nomino-NRK-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tvil-Forskning_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tvil-Forskning-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Anglo-Saxons of Britain also referred to the
       <a href="/wiki/Realm" title="Realm">
        kingdom
       </a>
       of Norway in 880 as
       <i>
        Norðmanna land
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nomino-NRK_26-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nomino-NRK-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tvil-Forskning_27-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tvil-Forskning-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There is some disagreement about whether the native name of Norway originally had the same etymology as the English form. According to the traditional undisputed view, the first component was originally
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nor%C3%B0r" title="wikt:norðr">
        <i>
         norðr
        </i>
       </a>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">
        cognate
       </a>
       of English
       <i>
        north
       </i>
       , so the full name was
       <i>
        Norðr
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vegr" title="wikt:vegr">
         vegr
        </a>
       </i>
       , "the way northwards", referring to the sailing route along the Norwegian coast, and contrasting with
       <i>
        suðrvegar
       </i>
       "southern way" (from
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Norse" title="Old Norse">
        Old Norse
       </a>
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/su%C3%B0r" title="wikt:suðr">
        suðr
       </a>
       ) for
       <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       , and
       <i>
        austrvegr
       </i>
       "eastern way" (from
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/austr" title="wikt:austr">
        austr
       </a>
       ) for the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">
        Baltic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eldar_Heide_28-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eldar_Heide-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to another theory, the first component was a word
       <i>
        nór
       </i>
       , meaning "narrow", referring to the inner-
       <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">
        archipelago
       </a>
       sailing route through the land ("narrow way"). The interpretation as "northern", as reflected in the English and Latin forms of the name, would then have been due to later
       <a href="/wiki/Folk_etymology" title="Folk etymology">
        folk etymology
       </a>
       . This latter view originated with philologist Niels Halvorsen Trønnes in 1847; since 2016 it as also advocated by language student and activist Klaus Johan Myrvoll and was adopted by
       <a href="/wiki/Philology" title="Philology">
        philology
       </a>
       professor
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Schulte" title="Michael Schulte">
        Michael Schulte
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nomino-NRK_26-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nomino-NRK-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tvil-Forskning_27-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tvil-Forskning-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The form
       <i>
        Nore
       </i>
       is still used in placenames such as the village of
       <a href="/wiki/Nore,_Norway" title="Nore, Norway">
        Nore
       </a>
       and lake
       <a href="/wiki/Norefjorden" title="Norefjorden">
        Norefjorden
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Buskerud" title="Buskerud">
        Buskerud
       </a>
       county, and still has the same meaning.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nomino-NRK_26-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nomino-NRK-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tvil-Forskning_27-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tvil-Forskning-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among other arguments in favour of the theory, it is pointed out that the word has a long vowel in Skaldic poetry and is not attested with &lt;ð&gt; in any native Norse texts or inscriptions (the earliest runic attestations have the spellings
       <i>
        nuruiak
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        nuriki
       </i>
       ). This resurrected theory has received some pushback by other scholars on various grounds, e. g. the uncontroversial presence of the element
       <i>
        norðr
       </i>
       in the ethnonym
       <i>
        norðrmaðr
       </i>
       "Norseman, Norwegian person" (modern Norwegian
       <i>
        nordmann
       </i>
       ), and the adjective
       <i>
        norrǿnn
       </i>
       "northern, Norse, Norwegian", as well as the very early attestations of the Latin and Anglo-Saxon forms with &lt;th&gt;.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eldar_Heide_28-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eldar_Heide-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tvil-Forskning_27-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tvil-Forskning-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In a Latin manuscript of 849, the name
       <i>
        Northuagia
       </i>
       is mentioned, while a French chronicle of c. 900 uses the names
       <i>
        Northwegia
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Norwegia
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sigurdsson_Riisoy_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sigurdsson_Riisoy-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When
       <a href="/wiki/Ohthere_of_H%C3%A5logaland" title="Ohthere of Hålogaland">
        Ohthere of Hålogaland
       </a>
       visited King
       <a href="/wiki/Alfred_the_Great" title="Alfred the Great">
        Alfred the Great
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
        England
       </a>
       in the end of the ninth century, the land was called
       <i>
        Norðwegr
       </i>
       (lit. "Northway") and
       <i>
        norðmanna land
       </i>
       (lit. "Northmen's land").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sigurdsson_Riisoy_29-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sigurdsson_Riisoy-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The adjective
       <i>
        Norwegian
       </i>
       , recorded from c. 1600, is derived from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Latin" title="Middle Latin">
        latinisation
       </a>
       of the name as
       <i>
        Norwegia
       </i>
       ; in the adjective
       <i>
        Norwegian
       </i>
       , the Old English spelling '-weg' has survived.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Old Norse
       <i>
        norðmaðr
       </i>
       was
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Latin" title="Middle Latin">
        Latinized
       </a>
       as
       <i>
        Nortmannus
       </i>
       in the ninth century to mean "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norseman" title="Norseman">
        Norseman
       </a>
       " and also "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viking" title="Viking">
        Viking
       </a>
       ", giving rise to the name of the
       <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">
        Normans
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After Norway had become
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christian
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        Noregr
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Noregi
       </i>
       had become the most common forms, but during the 15th century, the newer forms
       <i>
        Noreg(h)
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Norg(h)e
       </i>
       , found in medieval
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Icelandic
       </a>
       manuscripts, took over and have survived until the modern day.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Norway" title="History of Norway">
        History of Norway
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Scandinavia" title="History of Scandinavia">
        History of Scandinavia
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">
        Prehistory
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronze_Age_boats.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3336" data-file-width="3054" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Bronze_Age_boats.png/220px-Bronze_Age_boats.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Bronze_Age_boats.png/330px-Bronze_Age_boats.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Bronze_Age_boats.png/440px-Bronze_Age_boats.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bronze_Age_boats.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Bronze_Age" title="Nordic Bronze Age">
          Nordic Bronze Age
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_carvings" title="Rock carvings">
          rock carvings
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/Steinkjer" title="Steinkjer">
          Steinkjer
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Norway" title="Central Norway">
          Central Norway
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_prehistory" title="Scandinavian prehistory">
        Scandinavian prehistory
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The first inhabitants were the
       <a href="/wiki/Ahrensburg_culture" title="Ahrensburg culture">
        Ahrensburg culture
       </a>
       (11th to 10th millennia BC), which was a late
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">
        Upper Paleolithic
       </a>
       culture during the Younger Dryas, the last period of cold at the end of the Weichsel glaciation. The culture is named after the village of
       <a href="/wiki/Ahrensburg" title="Ahrensburg">
        Ahrensburg
       </a>
       , 25 km (15.53 mi) north-east of Hamburg in the
       <a href="/wiki/Schleswig-Holstein" title="Schleswig-Holstein">
        German state of Schleswig-Holstein
       </a>
       , where wooden arrow shafts and clubs have been excavated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Genetics_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Genetics-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The earliest traces of human occupation in Norway are found along the coast, where the huge ice shelf of the
       <a href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">
        last ice age
       </a>
       first melted between 11,000 and 8,000 BC. The oldest finds are stone tools dating from 9,500 to 6,000 BC, discovered in
       <a href="/wiki/Finnmark" title="Finnmark">
        Finnmark
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Komsa_culture" title="Komsa culture">
        Komsa culture
       </a>
       ) in the north and
       <a href="/wiki/Rogaland" title="Rogaland">
        Rogaland
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fosna-Hensbacka_culture" title="Fosna-Hensbacka culture">
        Fosna culture
       </a>
       ) in the south-west. However, theories about two altogether different cultures (the Komsa culture north of the
       <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Circle" title="Arctic Circle">
        Arctic Circle
       </a>
       being one and the Fosna culture from
       <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Trøndelag">
        Trøndelag
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Oslofjord" title="Oslofjord">
        Oslofjord
       </a>
       being the other) were rendered obsolete in the 1970s.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="598" data-file-width="1015" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg/260px-Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg/390px-Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg/520px-Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg.png 2x" width="260"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_Corded_Ware_culture-en.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Approximate extent of the
         <a href="/wiki/Corded_Ware_culture" title="Corded Ware culture">
          Corded Ware culture
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       More recent finds along the entire coast revealed to archaeologists that the difference between the two can simply be ascribed to different types of tools and not to different cultures. Coastal fauna provided a means of livelihood for fishermen and hunters, who may have made their way along the southern coast about 10,000 BC when the interior was still covered with ice. It is now thought that these so-called "Arctic" peoples came from the south and followed the coast northward considerably later.
      </p>
      <p>
       In the southern part of the country are dwelling sites dating from about 5,000 BC. Finds from these sites give a clearer idea of the life of the hunting and fishing peoples. The implements vary in shape and mostly are made of different kinds of stone; those of later periods are more skilfully made.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_carvings" title="Rock carvings">
        Rock carvings
       </a>
       (i.e. petroglyphs) have been found, usually near hunting and fishing grounds. They represent game such as
       <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">
        deer
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">
        reindeer
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">
        elk
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bear" title="Bear">
        bears
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">
        birds
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Earless_seal" title="Earless seal">
        seals
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">
        whales
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">
        fish
       </a>
       (especially
       <a href="/wiki/Salmon" title="Salmon">
        salmon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Halibut" title="Halibut">
        halibut
       </a>
       ), all of which were vital to the way of life of the coastal peoples. The carvings at
       <a href="/wiki/Alta,_Norway" title="Alta, Norway">
        Alta
       </a>
       in Finnmark, the largest in Scandinavia, were made at sea level from 4,200 to 500 BC and mark the progression of the land as the sea rose after the last ice age ended (
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_carvings_at_Alta" title="Rock carvings at Alta">
        Rock carvings at Alta
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Bronze_Age">
        Bronze Age
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Bronze Age">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Bronze_Age" title="Nordic Bronze Age">
        Nordic Bronze Age
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jordanes,_Norway_tribes.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="377" data-file-width="456" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jordanes%2C_Norway_tribes.png/260px-Jordanes%2C_Norway_tribes.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jordanes%2C_Norway_tribes.png/390px-Jordanes%2C_Norway_tribes.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Jordanes%2C_Norway_tribes.png 2x" width="260"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jordanes,_Norway_tribes.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Locations of the
         <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">
          Germanic
         </a>
         tribes described by
         <a href="/wiki/Jordanes" title="Jordanes">
          Jordanes
         </a>
         in Norway
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Between 3000 and 2500 BC new settlers (
       <a href="/wiki/Corded_Ware_culture" title="Corded Ware culture">
        Corded Ware culture
       </a>
       ) arrived in
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Norway" title="Eastern Norway">
        eastern Norway
       </a>
       . They were
       <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">
        Indo-European
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Farmers" title="Farmers">
        farmers
       </a>
       who grew
       <a href="/wiki/Grain" title="Grain">
        grain
       </a>
       and kept
       <a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">
        cows
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sheep" title="Sheep">
        sheep
       </a>
       . The hunting-fishing population of the west coast was also gradually replaced by farmers, though hunting and fishing remained useful secondary means of livelihood.
      </p>
      <p>
       From about 1500 BC,
       <a href="/wiki/Bronze" title="Bronze">
        bronze
       </a>
       was gradually introduced, but the use of stone implements continued; Norway had few riches to barter for bronze goods, and the few finds consist mostly of elaborate weapons and brooches that only chieftains could afford. Huge burial cairns built close to the sea as far north as
       <a href="/wiki/Harstad" title="Harstad">
        Harstad
       </a>
       and also inland in the south are characteristic of this period. The motifs of the rock carvings differ from those typical of the
       <a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">
        Stone Age
       </a>
       . Representations of the
       <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">
        Sun
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Animals" title="Animals">
        animals
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trees" title="Trees">
        trees
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Weapons" title="Weapons">
        weapons
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ships" title="Ships">
        ships
       </a>
       , and people are all strongly stylised.
      </p>
      <p>
       Thousands of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_carving" title="Rock carving">
        rock carvings
       </a>
       from this period depict ships, and the large stone burial monuments known as
       <a href="/wiki/Stone_ship" title="Stone ship">
        stone ships
       </a>
       , suggest that ships and seafaring played an important role in the culture at large. The depicted ships, most likely represent sewn plank built
       <a href="/wiki/Canoe" title="Canoe">
        canoes
       </a>
       used for warfare, fishing and trade. These ship types may have their origin as far back as the neolithic period and they continue into the Pre-Roman Iron Age, as exemplified by the
       <a href="/wiki/Hjortspring_boat" title="Hjortspring boat">
        Hjortspring boat
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Iron_Age">
        Iron Age
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Iron Age">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_Scandinavia" title="Iron Age Scandinavia">
        Iron Age Scandinavia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Little has been found dating from the early
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       (the last 500 years BC). The dead were cremated, and their graves contain few burial goods. During the first four centuries AD the people of Norway were in contact with Roman-occupied
       <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">
        Gaul
       </a>
       . About 70 Roman bronze cauldrons, often used as burial urns, have been found. Contact with the civilised countries farther south brought a knowledge of
       <a href="/wiki/Runes" title="Runes">
        runes
       </a>
       ; the oldest known Norwegian runic inscription dates from the 3rd century. At this time, the amount of settled area in the country increased, a development that can be traced by coordinated studies of
       <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">
        topography
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">
        archaeology
       </a>
       , and place-names. The oldest root names, such as nes, vik, and bø ("cape," "bay," and "farm"), are of great antiquity, dating perhaps from the Bronze Age, whereas the earliest of the groups of compound names with the suffixes vin ("meadow") or heim ("settlement"), as in Bjǫrgvin (Bergen) or Sǿheim (Seim), usually date from the 1st century AD.
      </p>
      <p>
       Archaeologists first made the decision to divide the Iron Age of Northern Europe into distinct pre-Roman and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Iron_Age" title="Roman Iron Age">
        Roman Iron Ages
       </a>
       after Emil Vedel unearthed a number of Iron Age artefacts in 1866 on the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Bornholm" title="Bornholm">
        Bornholm
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They did not exhibit the same permeating Roman influence seen in most other artefacts from the early centuries AD, indicating that parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        northern Europe
       </a>
       had not yet come into contact with the Romans at the beginning of the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Migration_period">
        Migration period
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Migration period">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2646" data-file-width="1838" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg/170px-Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg/255px-Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg/340px-Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Viking_swords_at_Bergen_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Viking_sword" title="Viking sword">
          Viking swords
         </a>
         found in Norway, preserved at
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bergen_Museum" title="Bergen Museum">
          Bergen Museum
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Migration_period" title="Migration period">
        Migration period
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Petty_kingdoms_of_Norway" title="Petty kingdoms of Norway">
        Petty kingdoms of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The destruction of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">
        Germanic peoples
       </a>
       in the 5th century is characterised by rich finds, including
       <a href="/wiki/Tribal_chief" title="Tribal chief">
        tribal chiefs
       </a>
       ' graves containing magnificent weapons and gold objects.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Hill forts were built on precipitous rocks for defence. Excavation has revealed stone foundations of farmhouses 18 to 27 metres (59 to 89 ft) long—one even 46 metres (151 feet) long—the roofs of which were supported on wooden posts. These houses were family homesteads where several generations lived together, with people and cattle under one roof.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       These states were based on either
       <a href="/wiki/Clan" title="Clan">
        clans
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Tribe" title="Tribe">
        tribes
       </a>
       (e.g., the
       <a href="/wiki/Horder" title="Horder">
        Horder
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Hordaland" title="Hordaland">
        Hordaland
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Norway" title="Western Norway">
        western Norway
       </a>
       ). By the 9th century, each of these small states had
       <a href="/wiki/Thing_(assembly)" title="Thing (assembly)">
        <i>
         things
        </i>
       </a>
       (local or regional assemblies),
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       for negotiating and settling disputes. The
       <i>
        thing
       </i>
       meeting places, each eventually with a
       <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B6rgr" title="Hörgr">
        hörgr
       </a>
       (open-air sanctuary) or a
       <a href="/wiki/Heathen_hof" title="Heathen hof">
        heathen hof
       </a>
       (temple; literally "hill"), were usually situated on the oldest and best farms, which belonged to the chieftains and wealthiest farmers. The regional
       <i>
        things
       </i>
       united to form even larger units: assemblies of deputy yeomen from several regions. In this way, the
       <i>
        lagting
       </i>
       (assemblies for negotiations and lawmaking) developed. The Gulating had its meeting place by
       <a href="/wiki/Sognefjord" title="Sognefjord">
        Sognefjord
       </a>
       and may have been the centre of an aristocratic confederation
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       along the western fjords and islands called the Gulatingslag. The Frostating was the assembly for the leaders in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trondheimsfjord" title="Trondheimsfjord">
        Trondheimsfjord
       </a>
       area; the
       <a href="/wiki/Earls_of_Lade" title="Earls of Lade">
        Earls of Lade
       </a>
       , near
       <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">
        Trondheim
       </a>
       , seem to have enlarged the Frostatingslag by adding the coastland from
       <a href="/wiki/Romsdalsfjord" title="Romsdalsfjord">
        Romsdalsfjord
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Lofoten" title="Lofoten">
        Lofoten
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Viking_Age">
        Viking Age
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Viking Age">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_(4835828216).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="900" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg/170px-Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg/255px-Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg/340px-Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_%284835828216%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_bateau_viking_dOseberg_(4835828216).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oseberg_ship" title="Oseberg ship">
          Oseberg ship
         </a>
         at the
         <a href="/wiki/Viking_Ship_Museum_(Oslo)" title="Viking Ship Museum (Oslo)">
          Viking Ship Museum
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
          Oslo
         </a>
         , Norway
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Viking_Age" title="Viking Age">
        Viking Age
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Norway" title="Unification of Norway">
        Unification of Norway
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hereditary_Kingdom_of_Norway" title="Hereditary Kingdom of Norway">
        Hereditary Kingdom of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="827" data-file-width="736" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg/150px-Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg/225px-Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg/300px-Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gjermundbu_helmet_-_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Gjermundbu_helmet" title="Gjermundbu helmet">
          Gjermundbu helmet
         </a>
         found in
         <a href="/wiki/Buskerud" title="Buskerud">
          Buskerud
         </a>
         is the only known reconstructable
         <a href="/wiki/Viking_Age" title="Viking Age">
          Viking Age
         </a>
         helmet
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       From the 8th to the 10th century, the wider Scandinavian region was the source of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viking" title="Viking">
        Vikings
       </a>
       . The looting of the monastery at
       <a href="/wiki/Lindisfarne" title="Lindisfarne">
        Lindisfarne
       </a>
       in Northeast England in 793 by
       <a href="/wiki/Norsemen" title="Norsemen">
        Norse people
       </a>
       has long been regarded as the event which marked the beginning of the
       <a href="/wiki/Viking_Age" title="Viking Age">
        Viking Age
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This age was characterised by expansion and emigration by Viking
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seafarer" title="Seafarer">
        seafarers
       </a>
       . They
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colonise" title="Colonise">
        colonised
       </a>
       , raided, and traded in all parts of Europe. Norwegian Viking explorers first discovered
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       by accident in the 9th century when heading for the
       <a href="/wiki/Faroe_Islands" title="Faroe Islands">
        Faroe Islands
       </a>
       , and eventually came across
       <a href="/wiki/Vinland" title="Vinland">
        Vinland
       </a>
       , known today as
       <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland_(island)" title="Newfoundland (island)">
        Newfoundland
       </a>
       , in
       <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
        Canada
       </a>
       . The Vikings from Norway were most active in the northern and western
       <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">
        British Isles
       </a>
       and eastern
       <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">
        North America
       </a>
       isles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to tradition,
       <a href="/wiki/Harald_Fairhair" title="Harald Fairhair">
        Harald Fairhair
       </a>
       unified them into one in 872 after the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hafrsfjord" title="Battle of Hafrsfjord">
        Battle of Hafrsfjord
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Stavanger" title="Stavanger">
        Stavanger
       </a>
       , thus becoming the first king of a united Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Harald's realm was mainly a South Norwegian coastal state. Fairhair ruled with a strong hand and according to the sagas, many Norwegians left the country to live in Iceland, the
       <a href="/wiki/Faroe_Islands" title="Faroe Islands">
        Faroe Islands
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">
        Greenland
       </a>
       , and parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">
        Britain
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">
        Ireland
       </a>
       . The modern-day Irish cities of
       <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">
        Dublin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Limerick" title="Limerick">
        Limerick
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Waterford" title="Waterford">
        Waterford
       </a>
       were founded by Norwegian settlers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Z%C3%BCge,_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2502" data-file-width="4026" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png/260px-Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png/390px-Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png/520px-Z%C3%BCge%2C_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png 2x" width="260"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Z%C3%BCge,_Landnahmen_und_Siedlungsgebiete_der_Nordm%C3%A4nner_-_800-1050.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norwegian, Danish and Swedish expansion during the Viking age between 800–1050
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Norse_mythology" title="Norse mythology">
        Norse traditions
       </a>
       were slowly replaced by
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_mythology" title="Christian mythology">
        Christian ones
       </a>
       in the late 10th and early 11th centuries. One of the most important sources for the history of the 11th century Vikings is the treaty between the Icelanders and Olaf Haraldsson, king of Norway circa 1015 to 1028.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is largely attributed to the missionary kings
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olaf_I_of_Norway" title="Olaf I of Norway">
        Olav Tryggvasson
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Olaf_II_of_Norway" title="Olaf II of Norway">
        St. Olav
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haakon_I_of_Norway" title="Haakon I of Norway">
        Haakon the Good
       </a>
       was Norway's first Christian king, in the mid-10th century, though his attempt to introduce the religion was rejected. Born sometime in between 963–969, Olav Tryggvasson set off raiding in
       <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
        England
       </a>
       with 390 ships. He attacked
       <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">
        London
       </a>
       during this raiding. Arriving back in Norway in 995, Olav landed in
       <a href="/wiki/Moster_(island)" title="Moster (island)">
        Moster
       </a>
       . There he built a church which became the first
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Moster_Church" title="Old Moster Church">
        Christian church
       </a>
       ever built in Norway. From Moster, Olav sailed north to
       <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">
        Trondheim
       </a>
       where he was proclaimed King of Norway by the Eyrathing in 995.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">
        Feudalism
       </a>
       never really developed in Norway or Sweden, as it did in the rest of Europe. However, the administration of government took on a very conservative feudal character. The
       <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">
        Hanseatic League
       </a>
       forced the royalty to cede to them greater and greater concessions over foreign trade and the economy. The League had this hold over the royalty because of the loans the Hansa had made to the royalty and the large debt the kings were carrying. The League's monopolistic control over the economy of Norway put pressure on all classes, especially the peasantry, to the degree that no real burgher class existed in Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Kalmar_Union">
        Kalmar Union
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Kalmar Union">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1200" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png/220px-Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png/330px-Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png/440px-Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Norwegian_Hereditary_Empire_excluding_Greenland.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norwegian Kingdom at its greatest extent, 1200s
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">
        Kalmar Union
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Empire" title="Norwegian Empire">
        Norwegian Empire
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Upon the death of
       <a href="/wiki/Haakon_V_of_Norway" title="Haakon V of Norway">
        Haakon V
       </a>
       (King of Norway) in 1319,
       <a href="/wiki/Magnus_IV_of_Sweden" title="Magnus IV of Sweden">
        Magnus Erikson
       </a>
       , at just three years old, inherited the throne as King Magnus VII of Norway. At the same time, a movement to make Magnus King of Sweden proved successful, and both the kings of Sweden and of Denmark were elected to the throne by their respective nobles, Thus, with his election to the throne of Sweden, both Sweden and Norway were united under King Magnus VII.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-larsen_41-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-larsen-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1349, the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">
        Black Death
       </a>
       radically altered Norway, killing between 50% and 60% of its population
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and leaving it in a period of social and economic decline.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The plague left Norway very poor. Although the death rate was comparable with the rest of Europe, economic recovery took much longer because of the small, scattered population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Even before the plague, the population was only about 500,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-end_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-end-44">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the plague, many farms lay idle while the population slowly increased.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the few surviving farms' tenants found their bargaining positions with their landlords greatly strengthened.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="463" data-file-width="499" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg/220px-Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg/330px-Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg/440px-Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kalmar_Union_ca._1400.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">
          Kalmar Union
         </a>
         c. 1400 AD
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       King Magnus VII ruled Norway until 1350, when his son, Haakon, was placed on the throne as
       <a href="/wiki/Haakon_VI_of_Norway" title="Haakon VI of Norway">
        Haakon VI
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_45-0">
