        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-45">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1363, Haakon VI married
       <a href="/wiki/Margaret_I_of_Denmark" title="Margaret I of Denmark">
        Margaret
       </a>
       , the daughter of King
       <a href="/wiki/Valdemar_IV_of_Denmark" title="Valdemar IV of Denmark">
        Valdemar IV of Denmark
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Upon the death of Haakon VI, in 1379, his son,
       <a href="/wiki/Olaf_II_of_Denmark" title="Olaf II of Denmark">
        Olaf IV
       </a>
       , was only 10 years old.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Olaf had already been elected to the throne of Denmark on 3 May 1376.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thus, upon Olaf's accession to the throne of Norway, Denmark and Norway entered
       <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">
        personal union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-46">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Olaf's mother and Haakon's widow, Queen Margaret, managed the foreign affairs of Denmark and Norway during the minority of Olaf IV.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Margaret was working toward a union of Sweden with Denmark and Norway by having Olaf elected to the Swedish throne. She was on the verge of achieving this goal when Olaf IV suddenly died.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, Denmark made Margaret temporary ruler upon the death of Olaf. On 2 February 1388, Norway followed suit and crowned Margaret.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enc_43-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-enc-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Queen Margaret knew that her power would be more secure if she were able to find a king to rule in her place. She settled on
       <a href="/wiki/Eric_of_Pomerania" title="Eric of Pomerania">
        Eric of Pomerania
       </a>
       , grandson of her sister. Thus at an all-Scandinavian meeting held at Kalmar, Erik of Pomerania was crowned king of all three Scandinavian countries. Thus, royal politics resulted in personal unions between the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic countries
       </a>
       , eventually bringing the thrones of Norway,
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       under the control of Queen Margaret when the country entered into the
       <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">
        Kalmar Union
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Union_with_Denmark">
        Union with Denmark
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Union with Denmark">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark%E2%80%93Norway" title="Denmark–Norway">
        Denmark–Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Norway" title="Greater Norway">
        Greater Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       After Sweden broke out of the
       <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">
        Kalmar Union
       </a>
       in 1521, Norway tried to follow suit,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       but the subsequent rebellion was defeated, and Norway remained in a union with Denmark until 1814, a total of 434 years. During the
       <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">
        national romanticism
       </a>
       of the 19th century, this period was
       <a href="/wiki/Nicolai_Wergeland" title="Nicolai Wergeland">
        by some
       </a>
       referred to as the "400-Year Night", since all of the kingdom's royal, intellectual, and administrative power was centred in
       <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">
        Copenhagen
       </a>
       in Denmark. In fact, it was a period of great prosperity and progress for Norway, especially in terms of shipping and foreign trade, and it also secured the country's revival from the demographic catastrophe it suffered in the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">
        Black Death
       </a>
       . Based on the respective natural resources, Denmark–Norway was in fact a very good match since Denmark supported Norway's needs for grain and food supplies, and Norway supplied Denmark with timber, metal, and fish.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_(Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten,_1660).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="647" data-file-width="1000" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg/220px-Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg/330px-Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg/440px-Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_%28Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten%2C_1660%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eerste_fase_van_de_Zeeslag_in_de_Sont_-_First_phase_of_the_Battle_of_the_Sound_-_November_8_1658_(Jan_Abrahamsz_Beerstraten,_1660).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Sound" title="Battle of the Sound">
          Battle of the Sound
         </a>
         between an allied Dano-Norwegian–
         <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">
          Dutch
         </a>
         fleet and the Swedish navy, 8 November 1658 (29 October
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Style" title="Old Style">
          O.S.
         </a>
         )
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With the
       <a href="/wiki/Reformation_in_Denmark%E2%80%93Norway_and_Holstein" title="Reformation in Denmark–Norway and Holstein">
        introduction of Protestantism
       </a>
       in 1536, the archbishopric in Trondheim was dissolved, and Norway lost its independence, and effectually became a
       <a href="/wiki/Colony" title="Colony">
        colony
       </a>
       of Denmark. The Church's incomes and possessions were instead redirected to the court in Copenhagen. Norway lost the steady stream of pilgrims to the relics of
       <a href="/wiki/Olaf_II_of_Norway" title="Olaf II of Norway">
        St. Olav
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/Nidaros" title="Nidaros">
        Nidaros
       </a>
       shrine, and with them, much of the contact with cultural and economic life in the rest of Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       Eventually restored as a kingdom (albeit in legislative union with Denmark) in 1661, Norway saw its land area decrease in the 17th century with the loss of the provinces
       <a href="/wiki/Bohusl%C3%A4n" title="Bohuslän">
        Båhuslen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A4mtland" title="Jämtland">
        Jemtland
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A4rjedalen" title="Härjedalen">
        Herjedalen
       </a>
       to Sweden, as the result of a number of disastrous wars with Sweden. In the north, however, its territory was increased by the acquisition of the northern provinces of
       <a href="/wiki/Troms" title="Troms">
        Troms
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Finnmark" title="Finnmark">
        Finnmark
       </a>
       , at the expense of Sweden and Russia.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">
        famine
       </a>
       of 1695–1696 killed roughly 10% of Norway's population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The harvest failed in Scandinavia at least nine times between 1740 and 1800, with great loss of life.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Union_with_Sweden">
        Union with Sweden
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Union with Sweden">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdoms_of_Sweden_and_Norway" title="United Kingdoms of Sweden and Norway">
        United Kingdoms of Sweden and Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norway_in_1814" title="Norway in 1814">
        Norwegian protectorate
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_romantic_nationalism" title="Norwegian romantic nationalism">
        Norwegian romantic nationalism
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2234" data-file-width="3330" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg/220px-Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg/330px-Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg/440px-Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eidsvoll_riksraad_1814.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The 1814 constitutional assembly, painted by
         <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wergeland" title="Oscar Wergeland">
          Oscar Wergeland
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After Denmark–Norway was attacked by the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">
        United Kingdom
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1807)" title="Battle of Copenhagen (1807)">
        Battle of Copenhagen
       </a>
       , it entered into an alliance with
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">
        Napoleon
       </a>
       , with the war leading to dire conditions and mass
       <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">
        starvation
       </a>
       in 1812. As the Danish kingdom found itself on the losing side in 1814, it was forced, under terms of the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Kiel" title="Treaty of Kiel">
        Treaty of Kiel
       </a>
       , to cede Norway to the king of Sweden, while the old Norwegian provinces of Iceland, Greenland, and the Faroe Islands remained with the Danish crown.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway took this opportunity to declare independence, adopted a constitution based on
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">
        American
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_France" title="Constitution of France">
        French
       </a>
       models, and elected the Crown Prince of Denmark and Norway,
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_VIII_of_Denmark" title="Christian VIII of Denmark">
        Christian Frederick
       </a>
       , as king on 17 May 1814. This is the famous
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Constitution_Day" title="Norwegian Constitution Day">
        Syttende Mai
       </a>
       (Seventeenth of May) holiday celebrated by Norwegians and Norwegian-Americans alike.
       <i>
        Syttende Mai
       </i>
       is also called
       <i>
        Norwegian Constitution Day
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Norwegian opposition to the great powers' decision to link Norway with Sweden caused the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish%E2%80%93Norwegian_War_(1814)" title="Swedish–Norwegian War (1814)">
        Norwegian-Swedish War
       </a>
       to break out as Sweden tried to subdue Norway by military means. As Sweden's military was not strong enough to defeat the Norwegian forces outright, and Norway's treasury was not large enough to support a protracted war, and as British and Russian navies blockaded the Norwegian coast,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the belligerents were forced to negotiate the
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_Moss" title="Convention of Moss">
        Convention of Moss
       </a>
       . According to the terms of the convention, Christian Frederik abdicated the Norwegian throne and authorised the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway" title="Parliament of Norway">
        Parliament of Norway
       </a>
       to make the necessary constitutional amendments to allow for the
       <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">
        personal union
       </a>
       that Norway was forced to accept. On 4 November 1814, the Parliament (Storting) elected
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_XIII_of_Sweden" title="Charles XIII of Sweden">
        Charles XIII of Sweden
       </a>
       as king of Norway, thereby establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_between_Sweden_and_Norway" title="Union between Sweden and Norway">
        union with Sweden
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under this arrangement, Norway kept its liberal constitution and its own independent institutions, except for the foreign service. Following the recession caused by the
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">
        Napoleonic Wars
       </a>
       , economic development of Norway remained slow until economic growth began around 1830.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="468" data-file-width="640" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg/220px-Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg/330px-Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg/440px-Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Havreskjering_Fossheim_Lindahl.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Harvesting of oats in
         <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8lster" title="Jølster">
          Jølster
         </a>
         , c. 1890
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       This period also saw the rise of the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_romantic_nationalism" title="Norwegian romantic nationalism">
        Norwegian romantic nationalism
       </a>
       , as Norwegians sought to define and express a distinct national character. The movement covered all branches of culture, including literature (
       <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Wergeland" title="Henrik Wergeland">
        Henrik Wergeland
       </a>
       [1808–1845],
       <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnstjerne_Bj%C3%B8rnson" title="Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson">
        Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson
       </a>
       [1832–1910],
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Christen_Asbj%C3%B8rnsen" title="Peter Christen Asbjørnsen">
        Peter Christen Asbjørnsen
       </a>
       [1812–1845],
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8rgen_Moe" title="Jørgen Moe">
        Jørgen Moe
       </a>
       [1813–1882]), painting (
       <a href="/wiki/Hans_Gude" title="Hans Gude">
        Hans Gude
       </a>
       [1825–1903],
       <a href="/wiki/Adolph_Tidemand" title="Adolph Tidemand">
        Adolph Tidemand
       </a>
       [1814–1876]), music (
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Grieg" title="Edvard Grieg">
        Edvard Grieg
       </a>
       [1843–1907]), and even language policy, where attempts to define a native written language for Norway led to today's two official written forms for Norwegian:
       <a href="/wiki/Bokm%C3%A5l" title="Bokmål">
        Bokmål
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nynorsk" title="Nynorsk">
        Nynorsk
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_XIV_John_of_Sweden" title="Charles XIV John of Sweden">
        King Charles III John
       </a>
       , who came to the throne of Norway and Sweden in 1818, was the second king following Norway's break from Denmark and the union with Sweden. Charles John was a complex man whose long reign extended to 1844. He protected the constitution and liberties of Norway and Sweden during the age of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Klemens_Wenzel,_Prince_von_Metternich" title="Klemens Wenzel, Prince von Metternich">
        Metternich
       </a>
       . As such, he was regarded as a liberal monarch for that age. However, he was ruthless in his use of paid informers, the secret police and restrictions on the
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">
        freedom of the press
       </a>
       to put down public movements for reform—especially the Norwegian national independence movement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
        Romantic Era
       </a>
       that followed the reign of King Charles III John brought some significant social and political reforms. In 1854, women won the right to inherit property in their own right, just like men. In 1863, the last trace of keeping unmarried women in the status of minors was removed. Furthermore, women were then eligible for different occupations, particularly the common school teacher.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By mid-century, Norway's democracy was limited by modern standards: Voting was limited to officials, property owners, leaseholders and burghers of incorporated towns.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saami_Family_1900.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2440" data-file-width="3320" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Saami_Family_1900.jpg/220px-Saami_Family_1900.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Saami_Family_1900.jpg/330px-Saami_Family_1900.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Saami_Family_1900.jpg/440px-Saami_Family_1900.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saami_Family_1900.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a href="/wiki/Sami_people" title="Sami people">
          Sami
         </a>
         family in Norway, c. 1900
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Still, Norway remained a conservative society. Life in Norway (especially economic life) was "dominated by the aristocracy of professional men who filled most of the important posts in the central government".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There was no strong bourgeosie class in Norway to demand a breakdown of this aristocratic control of the economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marx_Engels_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Marx_Engels-57">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thus, even while revolution swept over most of the countries of Europe in 1848, Norway was largely unaffected by revolts that year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marx_Engels_57-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Marx_Engels-57">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Thrane" title="Marcus Thrane">
        Marcus Thrane
       </a>
       was a Utopian socialist. He made his appeal to the labouring classes urging a change of social structure "from below upwards." In 1848, he organised a labour society in
       <a href="/wiki/Drammen" title="Drammen">
        Drammen
       </a>
       . In just a few months, this society had a membership of 500 and was publishing its own newspaper. Within two years, 300 societies had been organised all over Norway, with a total membership of 20,000 persons. The membership was drawn from the lower classes of both urban and rural areas; for the first time these two groups felt they had a common cause.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the end, the revolt was easily crushed; Thrane was captured and in 1855, after four years in jail, was sentenced to three additional years for crimes against the safety of the state. Upon his release, Marcus Thrane attempted unsuccessfully to revitalise his movement, but after the death of his wife, he migrated to the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1898, all men were granted
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
        universal suffrage
       </a>
       , followed by all
       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women's suffrage">
        women
       </a>
       in 1913.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger,_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="970" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg/150px-En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg/225px-En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg/300px-En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger%2C_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:En_brud_fr%C3%A5n_Hardanger,_Norge_-_Nordiska_Museet_-_NMA.0039996.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a href="/wiki/Bride" title="Bride">
          bride
         </a>
         from
         <a href="/wiki/Hardanger" title="Hardanger">
          Hardanger
         </a>
         , c. 1900
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Dissolution_of_the_union">
        Dissolution of the union
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Dissolution of the union">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_union_dissolution_referendum,_1905" title="Norwegian union dissolution referendum, 1905">
        Union dissolution referendum
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_union_between_Norway_and_Sweden" title="Dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden">
        Dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_Michelsen" title="Christian Michelsen">
        Christian Michelsen
       </a>
       , a shipping magnate and statesman, and Prime Minister of Norway from 1905 to 1907, played a central role in the peaceful separation of Norway from Sweden on 7 June 1905. A national referendum confirmed the people's preference for a monarchy over a republic. No Norwegian could legitimately claim the throne because none was able to prove relationship to medieval royalty and in European tradition
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_descent" title="Royal descent">
        royal
       </a>
       or "blue" blood is a precondition for laying claim to the throne.
      </p>
      <p>
       The government offered the throne of Norway to a prince of the Dano-German royal
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Gl%C3%BCcksburg" title="House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg">
        house of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg
       </a>
       . Prince Carl of Denmark was unanimously elected king by the Norwegian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway" title="Parliament of Norway">
        Parliament
       </a>
       , the first king of a fully independent Norway in 508 years (1397:
       <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">
        Kalmar Union
       </a>
       ); he took the name
       <a href="/wiki/Haakon_VII_of_Norway" title="Haakon VII of Norway">
        Haakon VII
       </a>
       . In 1905, the country welcomed the prince from neighbouring Denmark, his wife
       <a href="/wiki/Maud_of_Wales" title="Maud of Wales">
        Maud of Wales
       </a>
       and their young son to re-establish Norway's royal house. Following centuries of close ties between Norway and Denmark, a prince from the latter was the obvious choice for a European prince who could best relate to the Norwegian people.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_and_Second_World_Wars">
        First and Second World Wars
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: First and Second World Wars">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="949" data-file-width="699" height="299" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg/220px-Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg/330px-Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg/440px-Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Scenes from the
         <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Campaign" title="Norwegian Campaign">
          Norwegian Campaign
         </a>
         in 1940
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Norway" title="German occupation of Norway">
        German occupation of Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Norwegen" title="Reichskommissariat Norwegen">
        Reichskommissariat Norwegen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Quisling_regime" title="Quisling regime">
        Quisling regime
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_Norwegian_Forces" title="Free Norwegian Forces">
        Free Norwegian Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Throughout the
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        First World War
       </a>
       , Norway was in principle a neutral country. In reality, however, Norway had been pressured by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Britain and Ireland">
        British
       </a>
       to hand over increasingly large parts of its large merchant fleet to the British at low rates, as well as to join the trade blockade against Germany. Norwegian merchant marine ships, often with Norwegian sailors still on board, were then sailing under the British flag and at risk of being sunk by German submarines. Thus, many Norwegian sailors and ships were lost. Thereafter, the world ranking of the Norwegian merchant navy fell from fourth place to sixth in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway also proclaimed its neutrality during the
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        Second World War
       </a>
       , but despite this, it was
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung" title="Operation Weserübung">
        invaded by German forces
       </a>
       on 9 April 1940. Although Norway was unprepared for the German surprise attack (see:
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dr%C3%B8bak_Sound" title="Battle of Drøbak Sound">
        Battle of Drøbak Sound
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Campaign" title="Norwegian Campaign">
        Norwegian Campaign
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Norway" title="Invasion of Norway">
        Invasion of Norway
       </a>
       ), military and naval resistance lasted for two months. Norwegian armed forces in the north launched an offensive against the German forces in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Narvik" title="Battles of Narvik">
        Battles of Narvik
       </a>
       , until they were forced to surrender on 10 June after losing British support which had been diverted to France during the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_France" title="Battle of France">
        German invasion of France
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Haakon_VII_of_Norway" title="Haakon VII of Norway">
        King Haakon
       </a>
       and the Norwegian government escaped to
       <a href="/wiki/Rotherhithe" title="Rotherhithe">
        Rotherhithe
       </a>
       in London. Throughout the war they sent inspirational radio speeches and supported clandestine military actions in Norway against the Germans. On the day of the invasion, the leader of the small National-Socialist party
       <a href="/wiki/Nasjonal_Samling" title="Nasjonal Samling">
        Nasjonal Samling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vidkun_Quisling" title="Vidkun Quisling">
        Vidkun Quisling
       </a>
       , tried to seize power, but was forced by the German occupiers to step aside. Real power was wielded by the leader of the German occupation authority,
       <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissar" title="Reichskommissar">
        Reichskommissar
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Josef_Terboven" title="Josef Terboven">
        Josef Terboven
       </a>
       . Quisling, as
       <i>
        minister president
       </i>
       , later formed a
       <a href="/wiki/Quisling_regime" title="Quisling regime">
        collaborationist government under German control
       </a>
       . Up to 15,000 Norwegians volunteered to fight in German units, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Waffen-SS" title="Waffen-SS">
        Waffen-SS
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="1586" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg/220px-Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg/330px-Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg/440px-Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ole_Friele_Backer_norske_flygere.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norwegian fighter pilots in the United Kingdom during World War II
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The fraction of the Norwegian population that supported Germany was traditionally smaller than in Sweden, but greater than is generally appreciated today.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       It included a number of prominent personalities such as
       <a href="/wiki/Knut_Hamsun" title="Knut Hamsun">
        Knut Hamsun
       </a>
       . The concept of a "Germanic Union" of member states fit well into their thoroughly nationalist-patriotic ideology.
      </p>
      <p>
       Many Norwegians and persons of Norwegian descent joined the Allied forces as well as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_Norwegian_Forces" title="Free Norwegian Forces">
        Free Norwegian Forces
       </a>
       . In June 1940, a small group had left Norway following their king to Britain. This group included 13 ships, five aircraft, and 500 men from the Royal Norwegian Navy. By the end of the war, the force had grown to 58 ships and 7,500 men in service in the Royal Norwegian Navy, 5 squadrons of aircraft (including Spitfires, Sunderland flying boats and Mosquitos) in the newly formed Norwegian Air Force, and land forces including the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Independent_Company_1" title="Norwegian Independent Company 1">
        Norwegian Independent Company 1
       </a>
       and 5 Troop as well as No. 10
       <a href="/wiki/British_Commandos" title="British Commandos">
        Commandos
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the five years of
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Norway" title="German occupation of Norway">
        German occupation
       </a>
       , Norwegians built a
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_resistance_movement" title="Norwegian resistance movement">
        resistance movement
       </a>
       which fought the German occupation forces with both civil disobedience and armed resistance including the destruction of
       <a href="/wiki/Norsk_Hydro" title="Norsk Hydro">
        Norsk Hydro
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Heavy_water" title="Heavy water">
        heavy water
       </a>
       plant and stockpile of heavy water at
       <a href="/wiki/Vemork" title="Vemork">
        Vemork
       </a>
       , which crippled the German nuclear programme (see:
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_heavy_water_sabotage" title="Norwegian heavy water sabotage">
         Norwegian heavy water sabotage
        </a>
       </i>
       ). More important to the
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">
        Allied
       </a>
       war effort, however, was the role of the Norwegian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Merchant_Navy" title="Merchant Navy">
        Merchant Marine
       </a>
       . At the time of the
       <a href="/wiki/Invasion" title="Invasion">
        invasion
       </a>
       , Norway had the 4th largest merchant marine fleet in the world. It was led by the Norwegian shipping company
       <a href="/wiki/Nortraship" title="Nortraship">
        Nortraship
       </a>
       under the Allies throughout the war and took part in every war operation from the
       <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation" title="Dunkirk evacuation">
        evacuation of Dunkirk
       </a>
       to the
       <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">
        Normandy landings
       </a>
       . Each December Norway gives a
       <a href="/wiki/Christmas_tree" title="Christmas tree">
        Christmas tree
       </a>
       to the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
        United Kingdom
       </a>
       as thanks for the British assistance during the Second World War. A ceremony takes place to erect the tree in London's
       <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">
        Trafalgar Square
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Post-World_War_II_history">
        Post-World War II history
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Post-World War II history">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       From 1945 to 1962, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Labour_Party" title="Norwegian Labour Party">
        Labour Party
       </a>
       held an absolute majority in the parliament. The government, led by prime minister
       <a href="/wiki/Einar_Gerhardsen" title="Einar Gerhardsen">
        Einar Gerhardsen
       </a>
       , embarked on a program inspired by
       <a href="/wiki/Keynesian_economics" title="Keynesian economics">
        Keynesian economics
       </a>
       , emphasising state financed industrialisation and co-operation between
       <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">
        trade unions
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Employers%27_organisation" title="Employers' organisation">
        employers' organisations
       </a>
       . Many measures of state control of the economy imposed during the war were continued, although the
       <a href="/wiki/Rationing" title="Rationing">
        rationing
       </a>
       of dairy products was lifted in 1949, while price control and rationing of housing and cars continued as long as until 1960.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:StatfjordA(Jarvin1982).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="776" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/220px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/330px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/440px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:StatfjordA(Jarvin1982).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Since the 1980s oil production has helped to expand the Norwegian economy and finance the Norwegian state.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The wartime alliance with the United Kingdom and the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        United States
       </a>
       was continued in the post-war years. Although pursuing the goal of a socialist economy, the Labour Party distanced itself from the Communists (especially after the Communists' seizure of power in
       <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia" title="Czechoslovakia">
        Czechoslovakia
       </a>
       in 1948), and strengthened its foreign policy and defence policy ties with the US. Norway received
       <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">
        Marshall Plan
       </a>
       aid from the United States starting in 1947, joined the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
       </a>
       (OEEC) one year later, and became a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        North Atlantic Treaty Organization
       </a>
       (NATO) in 1949.
      </p>
      <p>
       The first oil was discovered at the small Balder field in 1967, production only began in 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1969, the
       <a href="/wiki/Phillips_Petroleum_Company" title="Phillips Petroleum Company">
        Phillips Petroleum Company
       </a>
       discovered
       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
        petroleum
       </a>
       resources at the
       <a href="/wiki/Ekofisk_oil_field" title="Ekofisk oil field">
        Ekofisk
       </a>
       field west of Norway. In 1973, the Norwegian government founded the State oil company,
       <a href="/wiki/Statoil" title="Statoil">
        Statoil
       </a>
       . Oil production did not provide net income until the early 1980s because of the large capital investment that was required to establish the country's petroleum industry. Around 1975, both the proportion and absolute number of workers in industry peaked. Since then labour-intensive industries and services like factory mass production and shipping have largely been outsourced.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway was a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">
        European Free Trade Association
       </a>
       (EFTA). Norway was twice invited to join the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , but ultimately declined to join after
       <a href="/wiki/Referendum" title="Referendum">
        referendums
       </a>
       which failed by narrow margins in 1972 and 1994.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg/220px-2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg/330px-2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg/440px-2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2011_Norway_attacks_flower_march_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Town Hall Square in Oslo filled with people with roses mourning the victims of the
         <a href="/wiki/2011_Norway_attacks#Utøya_massacre" title="2011 Norway attacks">
          Utøya massacre
         </a>
         , 22 July 2011
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1981, a Conservative government led by
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A5re_Willoch" title="Kåre Willoch">
        Kåre Willoch
       </a>
       replaced the Labour Party with a policy of stimulating the
       <a href="/wiki/Stagflation" title="Stagflation">
        stagflated economy
       </a>
       with tax cuts, economic liberalisation, deregulation of markets, and measures to curb record-high inflation (13.6% in 1981).
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway's first female prime minister,
       <a href="/wiki/Gro_Harlem_Brundtland" title="Gro Harlem Brundtland">
        Gro Harlem Brundtland
       </a>
       of the Labour party, continued many of the reforms of her conservative predecessor, while backing traditional Labour concerns such as
       <a href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">
        social security
       </a>
       , high taxes, the industrialisation of nature, and feminism. By the late 1990s, Norway had paid off its foreign debt and had started accumulating a
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund" title="Sovereign wealth fund">
        sovereign wealth fund
       </a>
       . Since the 1990s, a divisive question in politics has been how much of the income from petroleum production the government should spend, and how much it should save.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2011, Norway suffered
       <a href="/wiki/2011_Norway_attacks" title="2011 Norway attacks">
        two terrorist attacks
       </a>
       on the same day conducted by
       <a href="/wiki/Anders_Behring_Breivik" title="Anders Behring Breivik">
        Anders Behring Breivik
       </a>
       which struck the
       <a href="/wiki/Regjeringskvartalet" title="Regjeringskvartalet">
        government quarter
       </a>
       in Oslo and a summer camp of the Labour party's
       <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Youth_League_(Norway)" title="Workers' Youth League (Norway)">
        youth movement
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/Ut%C3%B8ya" title="Utøya">
        Utøya
       </a>
       island, resulting in 77 deaths and 319 wounded.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_parliamentary_election,_2013" title="Norwegian parliamentary election, 2013">
        2013 Norwegian parliamentary election
       </a>
       brought a more conservative government to power, with the
       <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(Norway)" title="Conservative Party (Norway)">
        Conservative Party
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Progress_Party_(Norway)" title="Progress Party (Norway)">
        Progress Party
       </a>
       winning 43% of the electorate's votes.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Norway" title="Geography of Norway">
        Geography of Norway
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Norway" title="Geology of Norway">
        Geology of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5820" data-file-width="4960" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg/220px-Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg/330px-Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg/440px-Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Norway_in_February_2003.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A satellite image of continental Norway in
         <a href="/wiki/Winter" title="Winter">
          winter
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway comprises the western part of
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">
        Scandinavia
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        Northern Europe
       </a>
       . The rugged coastline, broken by huge
       <a href="/wiki/Fjord" title="Fjord">
        fjords
       </a>
       and thousands of
       <a href="/wiki/Island" title="Island">
        islands
       </a>
       , stretches 25,000 kilometres (16,000 mi) and 83,000 kilometres (52,000 mi). Norway shares a 1,619-kilometre (1,006 mi) land border with
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       , 727 kilometres (452 mi) with
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       , and 196 kilometres (122 mi) with
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       to the east. To the north, west and south, Norway is bordered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">
        Barents Sea
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Sea" title="Norwegian Sea">
        Norwegian Sea
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
        North Sea
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Skagerrak" title="Skagerrak">
        Skagerrak
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_65-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Mountains" title="Scandinavian Mountains">
        Scandinavian Mountains
       </a>
       form much of the border with Sweden.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG/220px-Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG/330px-Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG/440px-Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Reine_Lofoten_2009.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Reine" title="Reine">
          Reine
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Lofoten" title="Lofoten">
          Lofoten
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Northern_Norway" title="Northern Norway">
          Northern Norway
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet,_2013_June.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3600" data-file-width="2405" height="329" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg/220px-Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg/330px-Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg/440px-Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet%2C_2013_June.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trollryggen_and_Trollveggen_from_Litlefjellet,_2013_June.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The tallest vertical rock face in Europe,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trollveggen" title="Trollveggen">
          Trollveggen
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Trollryggen" title="Trollryggen">
          Trollryggen
         </a>
         over the river
         <a href="/wiki/Rauma_(river)" title="Rauma (river)">
          Rauma
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Romsdalen" title="Romsdalen">
          Romsdalen
         </a>
         valley.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg/220px-The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg/330px-The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg/440px-The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Troll%27s_Tongue.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ringedalsvatnet" title="Ringedalsvatnet">
          Ringedalsvatnet
         </a>
         lake and
         <a href="/wiki/Trolltunga" title="Trolltunga">
          Trolltunga
         </a>
         cliff
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1056" data-file-width="1408" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg/220px-Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg/330px-Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg/440px-Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gaulosen_og_%C3%98ysand.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norwegian lowland landscape near the Gaulosen branch of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trondheimsfjord" title="Trondheimsfjord">
          Trondheimsfjord
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       At 385,252 square kilometres (148,747 sq mi) (including
       <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
        Svalbard
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Mayen" title="Jan Mayen">
        Jan Mayen
       </a>
       ) (and 323,802 square kilometres (125,021 sq mi) without), much of the country is dominated by mountainous or high terrain, with a great variety of natural features caused by prehistoric
       <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">
        glaciers
       </a>
       and varied
       <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">
        topography
       </a>
       . The most noticeable of these are the fjords: deep grooves cut into the land flooded by the sea following the end of the Ice Age.
       <a href="/wiki/Sognefjord" title="Sognefjord">
        Sognefjorden
       </a>
       is the world's second deepest fjord, and the world's longest at 204 kilometres (127 mi).
       <a href="/wiki/Hornindalsvatnet" title="Hornindalsvatnet">
        Hornindalsvatnet
       </a>
       is the deepest lake in all Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Permafrost" title="Permafrost">
        Permafrost
       </a>
       can be found all year in the higher mountain areas and in the interior of Finnmark county.
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_glaciers_in_Norway" title="List of glaciers in Norway">
        Numerous glaciers
       </a>
       are found in Norway.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway lies between latitudes
       <a href="/wiki/57th_parallel_north" title="57th parallel north">
        57°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/81st_parallel_north" title="81st parallel north">
        81° N
       </a>
       , and longitudes
       <a href="/wiki/4th_meridian_east" title="4th meridian east">
        4°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/32nd_meridian_east" title="32nd meridian east">
        32° E
       </a>
       . The land is mostly made of hard
       <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">
        granite
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gneiss" title="Gneiss">
        gneiss
       </a>
       rock, but
       <a href="/wiki/Slate" title="Slate">
        slate
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sandstone" title="Sandstone">
        sandstone
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestone
       </a>
       are also common, and the lowest elevations contain marine deposits. Because of the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">
        Gulf Stream
       </a>
       and prevailing westerlies, Norway experiences higher temperatures and more precipitation than expected at such northern latitudes, especially along the coast. The mainland experiences four distinct seasons, with colder winters and less precipitation inland. The northernmost part has a mostly maritime
       <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">
        Subarctic climate
       </a>
       , while Svalbard has an
       <a href="/wiki/Arctic" title="Arctic">
        Arctic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">
        tundra
       </a>
       climate.
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of the large latitudinal range of the country and the varied topography and climate, Norway has a larger number of different
       <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">
        habitats
       </a>
       than almost any other European country. There are approximately 60,000 species in Norway and adjacent waters (excluding bacteria and virus). The Norwegian Shelf large marine ecosystem is considered highly productive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The southern and western parts of Norway, fully exposed to Atlantic storm fronts, experience more precipitation and have milder winters than the eastern and far northern parts. Areas to the east of the coastal mountains are in a
       <a href="/wiki/Rain_shadow" title="Rain shadow">
        rain shadow
       </a>
       , and have lower rain and snow totals than the west. The lowlands around Oslo have the warmest and sunniest summers, but also cold weather and snow in wintertime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwegian-Meteorological-Institute_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwegian-Meteorological-Institute-68">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Book-Climate_69-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Book-Climate-69">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of Norway's high
       <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">
        latitude
       </a>
       , there are large seasonal variations in daylight. From late May to late July, the sun never completely descends beneath the horizon in areas north of the Arctic Circle (hence Norway's description as the "Land of the
       <a href="/wiki/Midnight_sun" title="Midnight sun">
        Midnight Sun
       </a>
       "), and the rest of the country experiences up to 20 hours of daylight per day. Conversely, from late November to late January, the sun never rises above the horizon in the north, and daylight hours are very short in the rest of the country.
      </p>
      <p>
       The coastal climate of Norway is exceptionally mild compared with areas on similar latitudes elsewhere in the world, with the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">
        Gulf Stream
       </a>
       passing directly offshore the northern areas of the Atlantic coast, continuously warming the region in the winter. Temperature anomalies found in coastal locations are exceptional, with
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B8st" title="Røst">
        Røst
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A6r%C3%B8y" title="Værøy">
        Værøy
       </a>
       lacking a meteorological winter in spite of being north of the Arctic Circle. The Gulf Stream has this effect only on the northern parts of Norway, not in the south, despite what is commonly believed. The northern coast of Norway would thus be ice-covered if not for the Gulf Stream.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a side-effect, the Scandinavian Mountains prevent continental winds from reaching the coastline, causing very cool summers throughout Atlantic Norway. Oslo has more of a continental climate, similar to Sweden's. The mountain ranges have subarctic and tundra climates. There is also very high rainfall in areas exposed to the Atlantic, such as Bergen. Oslo, in comparison, is dry, being in a
       <a href="/wiki/Rain_shadow" title="Rain shadow">
        rain shadow
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Skj%C3%A5k" title="Skjåk">
        Skjåk
       </a>
       in Oppland county is also in the rain shadow and is one of the driest places with 278 millimetres (10.9 inches) precipitation annually.
       <a href="/wiki/Finnmarksvidda" title="Finnmarksvidda">
        Finnmarksvidda
       </a>
       and the interior valleys of
       <a href="/wiki/Troms" title="Troms">
        Troms
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nordland" title="Nordland">
        Nordland
       </a>
       also receive less than 300 millimetres (12 inches) annually. Longyearbyen is the driest place in Norway with 190 millimetres (7.5 inches).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Parts of southeastern Norway including parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Mj%C3%B8sa" title="Mjøsa">
        Mjøsa
       </a>
       have warm-summer
       <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">
        humid continental climates
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
        Köppen
       </a>
       Dfb), while the more southern and western coasts are mostly of the
       <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
        oceanic climate
       </a>
       (Cfb). Further inland in southeastern and northern Norway, the
       <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">
        subarctic climate
       </a>
       (Dfc) dominates; this is especially true for areas in the rain shadow of the
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Mountains" title="Scandinavian Mountains">
        Scandinavian Mountains
       </a>
       . Some of the inner valleys of
       <a href="/wiki/Oppland" title="Oppland">
        Oppland
       </a>
       get so little precipitation annually, thanks to the rain shadow effect, that they meet the requirements for dry-summer subarctic climates (Dsc). In higher altitudes, close to the coasts of southern and western Norway, one can find the rare subpolar oceanic climate (Cfc). This climate is also common in Northern Norway, but there usually in lower altitudes, all the way down to sea level. A small part of the northernmost coast of Norway has the
       <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">
        tundra/alpine/polar climate
       </a>
       (ET). Large parts of Norway are covered by mountains and high altitude plateaus, many of which also exhibit the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tundra_climate" title="Tundra climate">
        tundra/alpine/polar climate
       </a>
       (ET).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwegian-Meteorological-Institute_68-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwegian-Meteorological-Institute-68">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Book-Climate_69-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Book-Climate-69">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>

        </td>

        </td>

        <th scope="row" style="height: 16px;">

        <td style="background: #E0E0FF; color:#000000;">
         −1.1
         <br/>

        <td style="background: #E3E3FF; color:#000000;">

         <br/>
         (47.1)
        </td>

         <br/>

         <br/>

        </td>

         <br/>
         (43.9)
        </td>

         <br/>
         (36)
        </td>
        <td style="background: #E6E6FF; color:#000000;">

         <br/>
         (31.8)
        </td>

         <br/>
         (42.1)
        </td>
       </tr>
