      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
        Biodiversity
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arcticfox-3.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="944" data-file-width="1280" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Arcticfox-3.jpg/220px-Arcticfox-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Arcticfox-3.jpg/330px-Arcticfox-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Arcticfox-3.jpg/440px-Arcticfox-3.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Arcticfox-3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Arctic_fox" title="Arctic fox">
          Arctic fox
         </a>
         has its habitat in high elevation ranges on the mainland as well as on
         <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
          Svalbard
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The total number of species include 16,000 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Insect" title="Insect">
        insects
       </a>
       (probably 4,000 more species yet to be described), 20,000 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">
        algae
       </a>
       , 1,800 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Lichen" title="Lichen">
        lichen
       </a>
       , 1,050 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Moss" title="Moss">
        mosses
       </a>
       , 2,800 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">
        vascular plants
       </a>
       , up to 7,000 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">
        fungi
       </a>
       , 450 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">
        birds
       </a>
       (250 species nesting in Norway), 90 species of
       <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">
        mammals
       </a>
       , 45 fresh-water species of fish, 150 salt-water species of fish, 1,000 species of fresh-water
       <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">
        invertebrates
       </a>
       , and 3,500 species of salt-water invertebrates.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 40,000 of these species have been described by science. The
       <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List" title="IUCN Red List">
        red list
       </a>
       of 2010 encompasses 4,599 species.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-red_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-red-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Joonis1.tif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="988" data-file-width="1581" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Joonis1.tif/lossless-page1-220px-Joonis1.tif.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Joonis1.tif/lossless-page1-330px-Joonis1.tif.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Joonis1.tif/lossless-page1-440px-Joonis1.tif.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Joonis1.tif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cold-water
         <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">
          coral reefs
         </a>
         in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Skagerak" title="Skagerak">
          Skagerak
         </a>
         off of the southern coast of Norway.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Seventeen species are listed mainly because they are endangered on a global scale, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_beaver" title="Eurasian beaver">
        European beaver
       </a>
       , even if the population in Norway is not seen as endangered. The number of threatened and near-threatened species equals to 3,682; it includes 418 fungi species, many of which are closely associated with the small remaining areas of old-growth forests,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       36 bird species, and 16 species of mammals. In 2010, 2,398 species were listed as endangered or vulnerable; of these were 1250 listed as vulnerable (VU), 871 as endangered (EN), and 276 species as critically endangered (CR), among which were the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grey_wolf" title="Grey wolf">
        grey wolf
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Arctic_fox" title="Arctic fox">
        Arctic fox
       </a>
       (healthy population on Svalbard) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Pool_frog" title="Pool frog">
        pool frog
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-red_81-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-red-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The largest predator in Norwegian waters is the
       <a href="/wiki/Sperm_whale" title="Sperm whale">
        sperm whale
       </a>
       , and the largest fish is the
       <a href="/wiki/Basking_shark" title="Basking shark">
        basking shark
       </a>
       . The largest predator on land is the
       <a href="/wiki/Polar_bear" title="Polar bear">
        polar bear
       </a>
       , while the
       <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">
        brown bear
       </a>
       is the largest predator on the Norwegian mainland. The largest land animal on the mainland is the elk (American English:
       <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">
        moose
       </a>
       ). The elk is in Norway known for its size and strength and is often called
       <i>
        skogens konge
       </i>
       , "king of the forest".
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">
        Environment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Environment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Attractive and dramatic scenery and landscape are found throughout Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The west coast of southern Norway and the coast of northern Norway present some of the most visually impressive coastal sceneries in the world.
       <a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">
        National Geographic
       </a>
       has listed the Norwegian fjords as the world's top tourist attraction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country is also home to the natural phenomena of the Midnight sun (during summer), as well as the
       <a href="/wiki/Aurora" title="Aurora">
        Aurora borealis
       </a>
       known also as the Northern lights.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2016
       <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">
        Environmental Performance Index
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">
        Yale University
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">
        Columbia University
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">
        World Economic Forum
       </a>
       put Norway in seventeenth place, immediately below Croatia and Switzerland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epi_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-epi-86">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The index is based on environmental risks to human health, habitat loss, and changes in CO2 emissions. The index notes over-exploitation of fisheries, but not
       <a href="/wiki/Whaling_in_Norway" title="Whaling in Norway">
        Norway's whaling
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Norway" title="Energy in Norway">
        oil exports
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indi_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-indi-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:center; max-width:1050px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet,_Stryn,_Norway,_2013_June_-_3.jpg" title="A summer evening view from Sande over Lovatnet in Stryn, Sogn og Fjordane, in 2013">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1330" data-file-width="6000" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg/1042px-Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg/1563px-Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg/2084px-Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet%2C_Stryn%2C_Norway%2C_2013_June_-_3.jpg 2x" width="1042"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Summer_evening_at_Lovatnet,_Stryn,_Norway,_2013_June_-_3.jpg" title="File:Summer evening at Lovatnet, Stryn, Norway, 2013 June - 3.jpg">
          </a>
         </div>
         A summer evening view from Sande over
         <a href="/wiki/Lovatnet" title="Lovatnet">
          Lovatnet
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Stryn" title="Stryn">
          Stryn
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Sogn_og_Fjordane" title="Sogn og Fjordane">
          Sogn og Fjordane
         </a>
         , in 2013
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">
        Politics and government
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Politics and government">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Norway" title="Politics of Norway">
        Politics of Norway
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Norway" title="Law of Norway">
        Law of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_parliamentary_election,_2017" title="Norwegian parliamentary election, 2017">
        Norwegian parliamentary election, 2017
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1764" data-file-width="3136" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg/220px-Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg/330px-Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg/440px-Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Det_Kongelige_Slott_85500_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Royal_Palace,_Oslo" title="Royal Palace, Oslo">
          The Royal Palace
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
          Oslo
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2312" data-file-width="1587" height="321" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg/220px-Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg/330px-Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg/440px-Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Wedding_Stockholm_2010-Konserthuset-411.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Harald_V_of_Norway" title="Harald V of Norway">
          King Harald V
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sonja_of_Norway" title="Sonja of Norway">
          Queen Sonja
         </a>
         of Norway, reigning since 1991.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Storting_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1008" data-file-width="1890" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Storting_01.jpg/220px-Storting_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Storting_01.jpg/330px-Storting_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Storting_01.jpg/440px-Storting_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Storting_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          The Storting
         </i>
         is the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway" title="Parliament of Norway">
          Parliament of Norway
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4632" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg/220px-Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg/330px-Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg/440px-Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Erna_Solberg_p%C3%A5_Kommunalkonferansen_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Erna_Solberg" title="Erna Solberg">
          Erna Solberg
         </a>
         , the
         <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Norway" title="Prime Minister of Norway">
          Prime Minister of Norway
         </a>
         since 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway is considered to be one of the most developed
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
        democracies
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rechtsstaat" title="Rechtsstaat">
        states of justice
       </a>
       in the world. From 1814, c. 45% of men (25 years and older) had the right to vote, whereas the United Kingdom had c. 20% (1832), Sweden c. 5% (1866), and Belgium c. 1.15% (1840). Since 2010, Norway has been classified as the world's most democratic country by the
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">
        Democracy Index
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Norway" title="Constitution of Norway">
        Constitution of Norway
       </a>
       , which was adopted on 17 May 1814
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Constitution-91">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and inspired by the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">
        United States Declaration of Independence
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">
        French Revolution
       </a>
       of 1776 and 1789, respectively, Norway is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
        constitutional monarchy
       </a>
       with a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary system
       </a>
       of government, wherein the
       <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Norway" title="Monarchy of Norway">
        King of Norway
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Norway" title="Prime Minister of Norway">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">
        head of government
       </a>
       . Power is separated among the legislative, executive and judicial branches of government, as defined by the Constitution, which serves as the country's supreme legal document.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Royal_Family" title="Norwegian Royal Family">
        Monarch
       </a>
       officially retains executive power. However, following the introduction of a parliamentary system of government, the duties of the Monarch have since become strictly representative and ceremonial,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       such as the formal appointment and dismissal of the Prime Minister and other ministers in the executive government. Accordingly, the Monarch is
       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">
        commander-in-chief
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Armed_Forces" title="Norwegian Armed Forces">
        Norwegian Armed Forces
       </a>
       , and serves as chief diplomatic official abroad and as a symbol of unity.
       <a href="/wiki/Harald_V_of_Norway" title="Harald V of Norway">
        Harald V
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Gl%C3%BCcksburg" title="House of Glücksburg">
        House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg
       </a>
       was crowned King of Norway in 1991, the first since the 14th century who has been born in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-norway.org_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-norway.org-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Haakon,_Crown_Prince_of_Norway" title="Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway">
        Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway
       </a>
       , is the legal and rightful heir to the throne and the Kingdom.
      </p>
      <p>
       In practice, the Prime Minister exercises the executive powers. Constitutionally, legislative power is vested with both the government and the Parliament of Norway, but the latter is the supreme legislature and a
       <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">
        unicameral
       </a>
       body.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway is fundamentally structured as a
       <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">
        representative democracy
       </a>
       . The Parliament can pass a law by simple majority of the 169 representatives, who are elected on the basis of
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       from 19 constituencies for four-year terms.
      </p>
      <p>
       150 are elected directly from the 19 constituencies, and an additional 19 seats ("levelling seats") are allocated on a nationwide basis to make the representation in parliament correspond better with the popular vote for the political parties. A 4% election threshold is required for a party to gain levelling seats in Parliament.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Election_threshold_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Election_threshold-95">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are a total of 169
       <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">
        Members of Parliament
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The Parliament of Norway, called the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway" title="Parliament of Norway">
         Stortinget
        </a>
       </i>
       (meaning Grand Assembly), ratifies national
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">
        treaties
       </a>
       developed by the executive branch. It can
       <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">
        impeach
       </a>
       members of the government if their acts are declared unconstitutional. If an indicted suspect is impeached, Parliament has the power to remove the person from office.
      </p>
      <p>
       The position of
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Norway" title="Prime Minister of Norway">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       , Norway's head of government, is allocated to the Member of Parliament who can obtain the
       <a href="/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence" title="Motion of no confidence">
        confidence
       </a>
       of a majority in Parliament, usually the current leader of the largest political party or, more effectively, through a coalition of parties. A single party generally does not have sufficient political power in terms of the number of seats to form a government on its own. Norway has often been ruled by minority governments.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Prime Minister nominates the Cabinet, traditionally drawn from members of the same political party or parties in the Storting, making up the government. The PM organises the executive government and exercises its power as vested by the Constitution.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway has a state church, the Lutheran
       <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Norway" title="Church of Norway">
        Church of Norway
       </a>
       , which has in recent years gradually been granted more internal autonomy in day-to-day affairs, but which still has a special constitutional status. Formerly, the PM had to have more than half the members of Cabinet be members of the Church of Norway, meaning at least ten out of the 19 ministries. This rule was however removed in 2012. The issue of
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">
        separation of church and state
       </a>
       in Norway has been increasingly controversial, as many people believe it is time to change this, to reflect the growing diversity in the population. A part of this is the evolution of the public school subject Christianity, a required subject since 1739. Even the state's loss in a battle at the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">
        European Court of Human Rights
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">
        Strasbourg
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in 2007 did not settle the matter. As of 1 January 2017, the Church of Norway is a separate legal entity, and no longer a branch of the civil service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Through the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Council_of_State" title="Norwegian Council of State">
        Council of State
       </a>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Privy_council" title="Privy council">
        privy council
       </a>
       presided over by the
       <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Norway" title="Monarchy of Norway">
        Monarch
       </a>
       , the Prime Minister and the Cabinet meet at the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Palace,_Oslo" title="Royal Palace, Oslo">
        Royal Palace
       </a>
       and formally consult the Monarch. All government bills need the formal approval by the Monarch before and after introduction to Parliament. The Council reviews and approves all of the Monarch's actions as head of state. Although all government and parliamentary acts are decided beforehand, the privy council is an example of symbolic gesture the King retains.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-norway.org_93-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-norway.org-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Members of the Storting are directly elected from
       <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">
        party-lists
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       in nineteen
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">
        plural-member
       </a>
       constituencies in a national
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party system
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Historically, both the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Labour_Party" title="Norwegian Labour Party">
        Norwegian Labour Party
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(Norway)" title="Conservative Party (Norway)">
        Conservative Party
       </a>
       have played leading political roles. In the early 21st century, the Labour Party has been in power since the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_parliamentary_election,_2005" title="Norwegian parliamentary election, 2005">
        2005 election
       </a>
       , in a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red-Green_Coalition" title="Red-Green Coalition">
        Red-Green Coalition
       </a>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Left_Party_(Norway)" title="Socialist Left Party (Norway)">
        Socialist Left Party
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Centre_Party_(Norway)" title="Centre Party (Norway)">
        Centre Party
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since 2005, both the Conservative Party and the
       <a href="/wiki/Progress_Party_(Norway)" title="Progress Party (Norway)">
        Progress Party
       </a>
       have won numerous seats in the Parliament, but not sufficient in the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_parliamentary_election,_2009" title="Norwegian parliamentary election, 2009">
        2009 general election
       </a>
       to overthrow the coalition. Commentators have pointed to the poor co-operation between the opposition parties, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(Norway)" title="Liberal Party (Norway)">
        Liberals
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Party_(Norway)" title="Christian Democratic Party (Norway)">
        Christian Democrats
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg" title="Jens Stoltenberg">
        Jens Stoltenberg
       </a>
       , the leader of the Labour Party, continues to have the necessary majority through his multi-party alliance to continue as PM.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In national elections in September 2013, voters ended eight years of Labor rule. Two political parties,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%B8yre" title="Høyre">
        Høyre
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Progress_Party_(Norway)" title="Progress Party (Norway)">
        Fremskrittspartiet
       </a>
       , elected on promises of tax cuts, more spending on infrastructure and education, better services and stricter rules on
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">
        immigration
       </a>
       , formed a government. Coming at a time when Norway's economy is in good condition with low unemployment, the rise of the right appeared to be based on other issues.
       <a href="/wiki/Erna_Solberg" title="Erna Solberg">
        Erna Solberg
       </a>
       became prime minister, the second female prime minister after
       <a href="/wiki/Gro_Harlem_Brundtland" title="Gro Harlem Brundtland">
        Brundtland
       </a>
       and the first conservative prime minister since
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_P._Syse" title="Jan P. Syse">
        Syse
       </a>
       . Solberg said her win was "a historic election victory for the right-wing parties".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Norway" title="Administrative divisions of Norway">
        Administrative divisions of Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Norway" title="Counties of Norway">
        Counties of Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Norway" title="Municipalities of Norway">
        Municipalities of Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_towns_and_cities_in_Norway" title="List of towns and cities in Norway">
        List of towns and cities in Norway
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Dependencies_of_Norway" title="Dependencies of Norway">
        Dependencies of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A1pmi_(area)" title="Sápmi (area)">
        Sápmi (area)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway, a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary state
       </a>
       , is divided into eighteen first-level administrative
       <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">
        counties
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        fylke
       </i>
       ). The counties are administrated through directly elected county assemblies who elect the County Governor. Additionally, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Royal_Family" title="Norwegian Royal Family">
        King
       </a>
       and government are represented in every county by a
       <a href="/wiki/County_governor_(Norway)" title="County governor (Norway)">
        fylkesmann
       </a>
       , who effectively acts as a
       <a href="/wiki/Governor" title="Governor">
        Governor
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As such, the Government is directly represented at a local level through the County Governors' offices. The counties are then sub-divided into 422 second-level
       <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">
        municipalities
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        kommuner
       </i>
       ), which in turn are administrated by directly elected municipal council, headed by a
       <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">
        mayor
       </a>
       and a small executive cabinet. The capital of
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
        Oslo
       </a>
       is considered both a county and a municipality.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway has two integral overseas territories:
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Mayen" title="Jan Mayen">
        Jan Mayen
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
        Svalbard
       </a>
       , the only developed island in the archipelago of the same name, located miles away to the north. There are three
       <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">
        Antarctic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Subantarctic" title="Subantarctic">
        Subantarctic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">
        dependencies
       </a>
       :
       <a href="/wiki/Bouvet_Island" title="Bouvet Island">
        Bouvet Island
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_I_Island" title="Peter I Island">
        Peter I Island
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Queen_Maud_Land" title="Queen Maud Land">
        Queen Maud Land
       </a>
       . On most maps, there had been an unclaimed area between Queen Maud Land and the
       <a href="/wiki/South_Pole" title="South Pole">
        South Pole
       </a>
       until 12 June 2015 when Norway formally annexed that area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_Norway_political-geo.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2902" data-file-width="1920" height="453" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Map_Norway_political-geo.png/300px-Map_Norway_political-geo.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Map_Norway_political-geo.png/450px-Map_Norway_political-geo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Map_Norway_political-geo.png/600px-Map_Norway_political-geo.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_Norway_political-geo.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A geopolitical map of Norway, showing the 19
         <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Norway" title="Counties of Norway">
          fylker
         </a>
         , the
         <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
          Svalbard
         </a>
         (Spitsbergen) and
         <a href="/wiki/Jan_Mayen" title="Jan Mayen">
          Jan Mayen
         </a>
         islands, which are part of the Norwegian kingdom
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       96 settlements have
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_towns_and_cities_in_Norway" title="List of towns and cities in Norway">
        city
       </a>
       status in Norway. In most cases, the city borders are coterminous with the borders of their respective municipalities. Often, Norwegian city municipalities include large areas that are not developed; for example, Oslo municipality contains large forests, located north and south-east of the city, and over half of Bergen municipality consists of mountainous areas.
      </p>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Original_research" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="40" data-file-width="40" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This table
          <b>
           possibly contains
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
            original research
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit">
            improve it
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            verifying
           </a>
           the claims made and adding
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
            inline citations
           </a>
           . Statements consisting only of original research should be removed.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (January 2018)
           </i>
          </small>

         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>

       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Norway_(%2Boverseas),_administrative_divisions_-_de_(zoom).svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1948" data-file-width="3188" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg/300px-Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg/450px-Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg/600px-Norway_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_de_%28zoom%29.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Norway_(%2Boverseas),_administrative_divisions_-_de_(zoom).svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norway and its overseas administrative divisions
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The counties of Norway are:
      </p>

          <img alt="Nord-Trøndelag våpen.svg" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="420" height="24" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg/20px-Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg/30px-Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg/40px-Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag_v%C3%A5pen.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Nord-Trøndelag">
          Trøndelag
         </a>
        </td>
