      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_reforms_2018-2020">
        Regional reforms 2018-2020
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Regional reforms 2018-2020">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Original_research" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="40" data-file-width="40" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           possibly contains
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
            original research
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit">
            improve it
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            verifying
           </a>
           the claims made and adding
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
            inline citations
           </a>
           . Statements consisting only of original research should be removed.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (January 2018)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">
             Learn how and when to remove this template message
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arkis" title="Arkis">
          Arkis
         </a>
        </b>
        -
        <a href="/wiki/Troms" title="Troms">
         Troms
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Finnmark" title="Finnmark">
         Finnmark
        </a>
        forms a new arctic region.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Nordland" title="Nordland">
          Nordland
         </a>
        </b>
        — Gets no changes.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Trøndelag">
          Trøndelag
         </a>
        </b>
        consisting of
        <a href="/wiki/Nord-Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Nord-Trøndelag">
         Nord-
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B8r-Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Sør-Trøndelag">
         Sør-Trøndelag
        </a>
        . The new region was formed on the 1. of January 2018.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B8re_og_Romsdal" title="Møre og Romsdal">
          Møre og Romsdal
         </a>
        </b>
        — Gets no changes.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vestlandet" title="Vestlandet">
          Vestlandet
         </a>
        </b>
        consisting of
        <a href="/wiki/Sogn_og_Fjordane" title="Sogn og Fjordane">
         Sogn og Fjordane
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Hordaland" title="Hordaland">
         Hordaland
        </a>
        . Named after the western region of Norway.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Rogaland" title="Rogaland">
          Rogaland
         </a>
        </b>
        — gets no changes.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Agder" title="Agder">
          Agder
         </a>
        </b>
        consisting of
        <a href="/wiki/Vest-Agder" title="Vest-Agder">
         Vest-
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Aust-Agder" title="Aust-Agder">
         Aust-Agder
        </a>
        . Equal to
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%B8rlandet" title="Sørlandet">
         Sørlandet
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Skagerrak" title="Skagerrak">
          Skagerrak
         </a>
        </b>
        the counties of
        <a href="/wiki/Telemark" title="Telemark">
         Telemark
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Vestfold" title="Vestfold">
         Vestfold
        </a>
        combines to make a natural region along the west coast of the
        <a href="/wiki/Oslofjord" title="Oslofjord">
         Oslofjord
        </a>
        . It is named after the stretch of sea outside its coast between Norway, Sweden and Denmark.
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Innlandet" title="Innlandet">
          Innlandet
         </a>
        </b>
        Consisting of
        <a href="/wiki/Oppland" title="Oppland">
         Oppland
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Hedmark" title="Hedmark">
         Hedmark
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
          Oslo
         </a>
        </b>
        —
       </li>
       <li>
        <b>
         <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Viken" title="Viken">
          Viken
         </a>
        </b>
        The biggest of the regions, containing huge part of the suburbs of Oslo. It is comparable to
        <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">
         Slovenia
        </a>
        in size and population, consisting of
        <a href="/wiki/Buskerud" title="Buskerud">
         Buskerud
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Akershus" title="Akershus">
         Akershus
        </a>
        og
        <a href="/wiki/%C3%98stfold" title="Østfold">
         Østfold
        </a>
        , all around Oslo. Named after the historical region of Viken, witch the Vikings might gave their name from.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Judicial_system_and_law_enforcement">
        Judicial system and law enforcement
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Judicial system and law enforcement">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Norway" title="Judiciary of Norway">
        Judiciary of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway uses a
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">
        civil law system
       </a>
       where laws are created and amended in Parliament and the system regulated through the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courts_of_justice_of_Norway" title="Courts of justice of Norway">
        Courts of justice of Norway
       </a>
       . It consists of the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Norway" title="Supreme Court of Norway">
        Supreme Court
       </a>
       of 20 permanent judges and a
       <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_Norway" title="Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Norway">
        Chief Justice
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Appellate_court" title="Appellate court">
        appellate courts
       </a>
       , city and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courts_of_justice_of_Norway#District_courts" title="Courts of justice of Norway">
        district courts
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conciliation_councils&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conciliation councils (page does not exist)">
        conciliation councils
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-norway_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-norway-105">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The judiciary is independent of executive and legislative branches. While the Prime Minister nominates Supreme Court Justices for office, their nomination must be approved by Parliament and formally confirmed by the Monarch in the Council of State. Usually, judges attached to regular courts are formally appointed by the Monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Courts' strict and formal mission is to regulate the Norwegian judicial system, interpret the Constitution, and as such implement the legislation adopted by Parliament. In its judicial reviews, it monitors the legislative and executive branches to ensure that they comply with provisions of enacted legislation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-norway_105-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-norway-105">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Norway" title="Law enforcement in Norway">
        law is enforced in Norway
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Police_Service" title="Norwegian Police Service">
        Norwegian Police Service
       </a>
       . It is a Unified National Police Service made up of 27 Police Districts and several specialist agencies, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_National_Authority_for_the_Investigation_and_Prosecution_of_Economic_and_Environmental_Crime" title="Norwegian National Authority for the Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crime">
        Norwegian National Authority for the Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crime
       </a>
       , known as
       <i>
        Økokrim
       </i>
       ; and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Criminal_Investigation_Service_(Norway)" title="National Criminal Investigation Service (Norway)">
        National Criminal Investigation Service
       </a>
       , known as
       <i>
        Kripos
       </i>
       , each headed by a chief of police. The Police Service is headed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Police_Directorate" title="National Police Directorate">
        National Police Directorate
       </a>
       , which reports to the Ministry of Justice and the Police. The Police Directorate is headed by a National Police Commissioner. The only exception is the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Police_Security_Service" title="Norwegian Police Security Service">
        Norwegian Police Security Agency
       </a>
       , whose head answers directly to the Ministry of Justice and the Police.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway abolished the death penalty for regular criminal acts in 1902. The legislature abolished the death penalty for high treason in war and war-crimes in 1979.
       <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
        Reporters Without Borders
       </a>
       , in its 2007 Worldwide Press Freedom Index, ranked Norway at a shared first place (along with Iceland) out of 169 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In general, the legal and institutional framework in Norway is characterised by a high degree of transparency, accountability and integrity, and the perception and the occurrence of corruption are very low.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway has ratified all relevant international anti-corruption conventions, and its standards of implementation and enforcement of anti-corruption legislation are considered very high by many international anti-corruption working groups such as the OECD Anti-Bribery Working Group. However, there are some isolated cases showing that some municipalities have abused their position in public procurement processes.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norwegian prisons are humane, rather than tough, with emphasis on rehabilitation. At 20%, Norway's re-conviction rate is among the lowest in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Norway" title="Foreign relations of Norway">
        Foreign relations of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norway_and_the_European_Union" title="Norway and the European Union">
        Norway and the European Union
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Whaling_in_Norway" title="Whaling in Norway">
        Whaling in Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg/220px-KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg/330px-KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg/440px-KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KNM_Fridtjof_Nansen-2006-06-01-side.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Royal_Norwegian_Navy" title="Royal Norwegian Navy">
          Royal Norwegian Navy
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen-class_frigate" title="Fridtjof Nansen-class frigate">
          <i>
           Fridtjof Nansen
          </i>
          class frigate
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway maintains embassies in 82 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       60 countries maintain an embassy in Norway, all of them in the capital, Oslo.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway is a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       (UN), the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        North Atlantic Treaty Organization
       </a>
       (NATO), the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       and the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). Norway issued applications for accession to the European Union (EU) and its predecessors in 1962, 1967 and 1992, respectively. While Denmark, Sweden and Finland obtained membership, the Norwegian electorate rejected the treaties of accession in referenda in 1972 and 1994.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the 1994 referendum, Norway maintained its membership in the European Economic Area (EEA), an arrangement granting the country access to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Single_market_of_the_European_Union" title="Single market of the European Union">
        internal market
       </a>
       of the Union, on the condition that Norway implements the Union's pieces of legislation which are deemed relevant (of which there were approximately seven thousand by 2010)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Successive Norwegian governments have, since 1994, requested participation in parts of the EU's co-operation that go beyond the provisions of the EEA agreement. Non-voting participation by Norway has been granted in, for instance, the Union's
       <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">
        Common Security and Defence Policy
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">
        Schengen Agreement
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Defence_Agency" title="European Defence Agency">
        European Defence Agency
       </a>
       , as well as 19 separate programmes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway contributes to
       <a href="/wiki/International_development" title="International development">
        international development
       </a>
       . In addition, it participated in the 1990s brokering of the
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Accords" title="Oslo Accords">
        Oslo Accords
       </a>
       , an attempt to resolve the
       <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="Israeli–Palestinian conflict">
        Israeli–Palestinian conflict
       </a>
       . These were unsuccessful.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Military">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Armed_Forces" title="Norwegian Armed Forces">
        Norwegian Armed Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Norwegian_F-35.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="2100" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/First_Norwegian_F-35.png/220px-First_Norwegian_F-35.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/First_Norwegian_F-35.png/330px-First_Norwegian_F-35.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/First_Norwegian_F-35.png/440px-First_Norwegian_F-35.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Norwegian_F-35.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The first Norwegian
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-35_Lightning_II" title="F-35 Lightning II">
          F-35 Lightning II
         </a>
         lands at Luke Air Force Base
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1910" data-file-width="2860" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg/220px-2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg/330px-2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg/440px-2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2_norwegian_Leopard_tanks_in_the_snow.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norwegian
         <a href="/wiki/Leopard_1" title="Leopard 1">
          Leopard
         </a>
         tanks in the snow in
         <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A5lselv" title="Målselv">
          Målselv
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Norwegian Armed Forces numbers about 25,000 personnel, including civilian employees. According to 2009 mobilisation plans, full mobilisation produces approximately 83,000 combatant personnel. Norway has
       <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">
        conscription
       </a>
       (including 6–12 months of training);
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NDFnumbers_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NDFnumbers-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in 2013, the country became the first in Europe and NATO to draft women as well as men. However, due to less need for conscripts after the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       ended with the break-up of the Soviet Union, few people have to serve if they are not motivated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Armed Forces are subordinate to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Ministry_of_Defence" title="Norwegian Ministry of Defence">
        Norwegian Ministry of Defence
       </a>
       . The Commander-in-Chief is
       <a href="/wiki/Harald_V_of_Norway" title="Harald V of Norway">
        King Harald V
       </a>
       . The military of Norway is divided into the following branches: the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Army" title="Norwegian Army">
        Norwegian Army
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Norwegian_Navy" title="Royal Norwegian Navy">
        Royal Norwegian Navy
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Norwegian_Air_Force" title="Royal Norwegian Air Force">
        Royal Norwegian Air Force
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Cyber_Defence_Force" title="Norwegian Cyber Defence Force">
        Norwegian Cyber Defence Force
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_Guard_(Norway)" title="Home Guard (Norway)">
        Home Guard
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In response to its being overrun by Germany in 1940, the country was one of the founding nations of the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        North Atlantic Treaty Organization
       </a>
       (NATO) on 4 April 1949. At present, Norway contributes in the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
        International Security Assistance Force
       </a>
       (ISAF) in
       <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present)">
        Afghanistan
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Additionally, Norway has contributed in several missions in contexts of the United Nations, NATO, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">
        Common Security and Defence Policy
       </a>
       of the European Union.
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Health">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Norway" title="Health in Norway">
        Health in Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway was awarded first place according to the UN's
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       (HDI) for 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Poverty and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communicable_disease" title="Communicable disease">
        communicable diseases
       </a>
       dominated in Norway together with
       <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">
        famines
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">
        epidemics
       </a>
       in the 1800s. From the 1900s, improvements in public health occurred as a result of development in several areas such as social and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Living_condition" title="Living condition">
        living conditions
       </a>
       , changes in disease and medical outbreaks, establishment of the health care system, and emphasis on public health matters.
       <a href="/wiki/Vaccination" title="Vaccination">
        Vaccination
       </a>
       and increased treatment opportunities with antibiotics resulted in great improvements within the Norwegian population. Improved hygiene and better nutrition were factors that contributed to improved health.
      </p>
      <p>
       The disease pattern in Norway changed from communicable diseases to non-communicable diseases and chronic diseases as
       <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">
        cardiovascular disease
       </a>
       . Inequalities and social differences are still present in public health in Norway today.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Folkehelse_i_Norge_1814_–_2014_116-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Folkehelse_i_Norge_1814_–_2014-116">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013 the infant mortality rate was 2.5 per 1,000 live births among children under the age of one. For girls it was 2.7 and for boys 2.3, which is the lowest infant mortality rate for boys ever recorded in Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Norway" title="Economy of Norway">
        Economy of Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Norway" title="Energy in Norway">
        Energy in Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">
        European Economic Area
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone#Norway" title="Exclusive economic zone">
        Exclusive economic zone § Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Norway_treemap.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="867" data-file-width="1108" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Norway_treemap.png/300px-Norway_treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Norway_treemap.png/450px-Norway_treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Norway_treemap.png/600px-Norway_treemap.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Norway_treemap.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Graphical depiction of Norway's product exports in 28 colour-coded categories.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="569" data-file-width="880" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG/300px-GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG/450px-GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG/600px-GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GDP_Norway_1865_to_2004.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         GDP and GDP growth
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norwegians enjoy the second-highest
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">
        GDP per-capita
       </a>
       among European countries (after
       <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">
        Luxembourg
       </a>
       ), and the sixth-highest
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">
        GDP (PPP) per-capita
       </a>
       in the world. Today, Norway ranks as the second-wealthiest country in the world in monetary value, with the largest capital reserve per capita of any nation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the CIA World Factbook, Norway is a net external creditor of debt.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_65-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway maintained first place in the world in the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">
        UNDP
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       (HDI) for six consecutive years (2001–2006),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_10-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HDI-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and then reclaimed this position in 2009, through 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI2_21-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HDI2-21">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The standard of living in Norway is among the highest in the world.
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Policy" title="Foreign Policy">
         Foreign Policy
        </a>
       </i>
       magazine ranks Norway last in its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Failed_States_Index" title="List of countries by Failed States Index">
        Failed States Index
       </a>
       for 2009, judging Norway to be the world's most well-functioning and stable country. The
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       ranks Norway fourth in the 2013 equalised
       <a href="/wiki/OECD_Better_Life_Index" title="OECD Better Life Index">
        Better Life Index
       </a>
       and third in intergenerational earnings elasticity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_Better_Life_Index_120-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-OECD_Better_Life_Index-120">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="800" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg/300px-Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg/450px-Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg/600px-Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_waters_-_Norway.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Norway's exclusive economic zones
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Norwegian economy is an example of a
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">
        mixed economy
       </a>
       , a prosperous capitalist
       <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">
        welfare state
       </a>
       and social democracy country featuring a combination of
       <a href="/wiki/Free_market" title="Free market">
        free market
       </a>
       activity and large state ownership in certain key sectors.
       <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Norway" title="Healthcare in Norway">
        Public health care in Norway
       </a>
       is free (after an annual charge of around 2000
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_krone" title="Norwegian krone">
        kroner
       </a>
       for those over 16), and parents have 46 weeks paid
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       parental leave. The state income derived from natural resources includes a significant contribution from petroleum production. Norway has an unemployment rate of 4.8%, with 68% of the population aged 15–74 employed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       People in the labour force are either employed or looking for work.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       9.5% of the population aged 18–66 receive a disability pension
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 30% of the labour force are employed by the government, the highest in the
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The hourly productivity levels, as well as average hourly wages in Norway, are among the highest in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Egalitarianism" title="Egalitarianism">
        egalitarian
       </a>
       values of Norwegian society have kept the wage difference between the lowest paid worker and the CEO of most companies as much less than in comparable western economies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is also evident in
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">
        Norway's low Gini coefficient
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The state has large ownership positions in key industrial sectors, such as the strategic
       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
        petroleum
       </a>
       sector (
       <a href="/wiki/Statoil" title="Statoil">
        Statoil
       </a>
       ), hydroelectric energy production (
       <a href="/wiki/Statkraft" title="Statkraft">
        Statkraft
       </a>
       ), aluminium production (
       <a href="/wiki/Norsk_Hydro" title="Norsk Hydro">
        Norsk Hydro
       </a>
       ), the largest Norwegian bank (
       <a href="/wiki/DNB_ASA" title="DNB ASA">
        DNB
       </a>
       ), and telecommunication provider (
       <a href="/wiki/Telenor" title="Telenor">
        Telenor
       </a>
       ). Through these big companies, the government controls approximately 30% of the stock values at the Oslo Stock Exchange. When non-listed companies are included, the state has even higher share in ownership (mainly from direct oil licence ownership). Norway is a major
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shipping" title="Shipping">
        shipping
       </a>
       nation and has the world's 6th largest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ship_transport" title="Ship transport">
        merchant fleet
       </a>
       , with 1,412 Norwegian-owned merchant vessels.
      </p>
      <p>
       By referendums in 1972 and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_European_Union_membership_referendum,_1994" title="Norwegian European Union membership referendum, 1994">
        1994
       </a>
       , Norwegians rejected proposals to join the European Union (EU). However, Norway, together with
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">
        Liechtenstein
       </a>
       , participates in the European Union's single market through the European Economic Area (EEA) agreement. The EEA Treaty between the European Union countries and the EFTA countries– transposed into Norwegian law via "EØS-loven"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       – describes the procedures for implementing European Union rules in Norway and the other EFTA countries. Norway is a highly integrated member of most sectors of the EU internal market. Some sectors, such as agriculture, oil and fish, are not wholly covered by the EEA Treaty. Norway has also acceded to the
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">
        Schengen Agreement
       </a>
       and several other intergovernmental agreements among the EU member states.
      </p>
      <p>
       The country is richly endowed with natural resources including
       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
        petroleum
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">
        hydropower
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">
        fish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">
        forests
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Mineral" title="Mineral">
        minerals
       </a>
       . Large reserves of petroleum and
       <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
        natural gas
       </a>
       were discovered in the 1960s, which led to a boom in the economy. Norway has obtained one of the highest standards of living in the world in part by having a large amount of natural resources compared to the size of the population. In 2011, 28% of state revenues were generated from the petroleum industry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway is the first country which banned cutting of trees (deforestation), in order to prevent rain forests from vanishing. The country declared its intention at the UN Climate Summit in 2014, alongside Great Britain and Germany. Crops, that are typically linked to forests' destruction are timber, soy, palm oil and beef. Now Norway has to find new way to provide these essential products without exerting negative influence on its environment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Resources">
        Resources
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Resources">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG/220px-Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG/330px-Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG/440px-Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fredvang_Lofoten_2009_2.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Agriculture is a significant sector, in spite of the mountainous landscape (
         <a href="/wiki/Flakstad" title="Flakstad">
          Flakstad
         </a>
         )
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:StatfjordA(Jarvin1982).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="776" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/220px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/330px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg/440px-StatfjordA%28Jarvin1982%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:StatfjordA(Jarvin1982).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Oil production has been central to the Norwegian economy since the 1970s, with a dominating
         <a href="/wiki/State_ownership" title="State ownership">
          state ownership
         </a>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/Statfjord_oil_field" title="Statfjord oil field">
          Statfjord oil field
         </a>
         )
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1500" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg/220px-Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg/330px-Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg/440px-Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stockfish_in_Lofoten.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Stockfish" title="Stockfish">
          Stockfish
         </a>
         has been exported from
         <a href="/wiki/Lofoten" title="Lofoten">
          Lofoten
         </a>
         in Norway for at least 1,000 years
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Export revenues from oil and gas have risen to almost 50% of total exports and constitute more than 20% of the
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        GDP
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway is the fifth-largest oil exporter and third-largest gas exporter in the world, but it is not a member of
       <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">
        OPEC
       </a>
       . In 1995, the Norwegian government established the sovereign wealth fund (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Government_Pension_Fund_of_Norway" title="The Government Pension Fund of Norway">
        "Government Pension Fund — Global"
       </a>
       ), which would be funded with oil revenues, including taxes, dividends, sales revenues and licensing fees. This was intended to reduce overheating in the economy from oil revenues, minimise uncertainty from volatility in oil price, and provide a cushion to compensate for expenses associated with the ageing of the population.
      </p>
      <p>
       The government controls its petroleum resources through a combination of state ownership in major operators in the oil fields (with approximately 62% ownership in
       <a href="/wiki/Statoil" title="Statoil">
        Statoil
       </a>
       in 2007) and the fully state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Petoro" title="Petoro">
        Petoro
       </a>
       , which has a market value of about twice Statoil, and
       <a href="/wiki/State%27s_Direct_Financial_Interest" title="State's Direct Financial Interest">
        SDFI
       </a>
       . Finally, the government controls licensing of exploration and production of fields. The fund invests in developed financial markets outside Norway. The budgetary rule (
       <i>
        Handlingsregelen
       </i>
       ) is to spend no more than 4% of the fund each year (assumed to be the normal yield from the fund).
      </p>
      <p>
       In March 2017, the Government Pension Fund controlled assets were valued at approximately US$913 billion (equal to US$182,000 per capita), which is about 178% of Norway's current GDP. It is the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund" title="Sovereign wealth fund">
        sovereign wealth fund
       </a>
       in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The fund controls about 1.3% of all listed shares in Europe, and more than 1% of all the publicly traded shares in the world. The Norwegian Central Bank operates investment offices in London, New York, and Shanghai. Guidelines implemented in 2007 allow the fund to invest up to 60% of the capital in shares (maximum of 40% prior), while the rest may be placed in bonds and real-estate. As the stock markets tumbled in September 2008, the fund was able to buy more shares at low prices. In this way, the losses incurred by the market turmoil was recuperated by November 2009.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Other nations with economies based on natural resources, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       , are trying to learn from Norway by establishing similar funds. The investment choices of the Norwegian fund are directed by
       <a href="/wiki/Socially_responsible_investing" title="Socially responsible investing">
        ethical guidelines
       </a>
       ; for example, the fund is not allowed to invest in companies that produce parts for nuclear weapons. Norway's highly
       <a href="/wiki/Transparency_(market)" title="Transparency (market)">
        transparent
       </a>
       investment scheme is lauded by the international community.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The future size of the fund is closely linked to the price of oil and to developments in international financial markets.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2000, the government sold one-third of the state-owned oil company Statoil in an
       <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">
        IPO
       </a>
       . The next year, the main telecom supplier,
       <a href="/wiki/Telenor" title="Telenor">
        Telenor
       </a>
       , was listed on
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Stock_Exchange" title="Oslo Stock Exchange">
        Oslo Stock Exchange
       </a>
       . The state also owns significant shares of Norway's largest bank,
       <a href="/wiki/DNB_ASA" title="DNB ASA">
        DnB NOR
       </a>
       and the airline
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines" title="Scandinavian Airlines">
        SAS
       </a>
       . Since 2000,
       <a href="/wiki/Economic_growth" title="Economic growth">
        economic growth
       </a>
       has been rapid, pushing unemployment down to levels not seen since the early 1980s (unemployment in 2007: 1.3%). The international financial crisis has primarily affected the industrial sector, but unemployment has remained low, and was at 3.3% (86,000 people) in August 2011. In contrast to Norway,
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       had substantially higher actual and projected unemployment numbers as a result of the recession. Thousands of mainly young Swedes migrated to Norway for work during these years, which is easy, as the labour market and social security systems overlap in the Nordic Countries. In the first quarter of 2009, the GNP of Norway surpassed Sweden's for the first time in history, although its population is half the size.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway contains significant
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mineral_resources" title="Mineral resources">
        mineral resources
       </a>
       , and in 2013, its mineral production was valued at US$1.5 billion (Norwegian Geological Survey data). The most valuable minerals are calcium carbonate (
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestone
       </a>
       ), building stone,
       <a href="/wiki/Nepheline_syenite" title="Nepheline syenite">
        nepheline syenite
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olivine" title="Olivine">
        olivine
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Iron" title="Iron">
        iron
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Titanium" title="Titanium">
        titanium
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">
        nickel
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway is also the world's second-largest exporter of fish (in value, after China).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GGT_135-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GGT-135">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">
        Hydroelectric plants
       </a>
       generate roughly 98–99% of Norway's electric power, more than any other country in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Oil_fields">
        Oil fields
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Oil fields">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;float: right; clear: right; margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em">
       <caption>
        External image
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align: left">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="512" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/61/Searchtool.svg/16px-Searchtool.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/61/Searchtool.svg/24px-Searchtool.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/61/Searchtool.svg/32px-Searchtool.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.tu.no/petroleum/2014/12/11/her-ser-du-hvorfor-oljeprisen-faller" rel="nofollow">
          Decreasing oil production
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Between 1966 and 2013, Norwegian companies drilled 5085
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_well" title="Oil well">
        oil wells
       </a>
       , mostly in the
       <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
        North Sea
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells_138-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Of these 3672 are
       <i>
        utviklingsbrønner
       </i>
       (regular production);
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells_138-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       1413 are
       <i>
        letebrønner
       </i>
       (exploration); and 1405 have been terminated (
       <i>
        avsluttet
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells_138-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwegianSectorOnly?4053wells-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Oil fields not yet in production phase include:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Wisting_Central&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Wisting Central (page does not exist)">
        Wisting Central
       </a>
       —calculated size in 2013, 65–156 million barrels of oil and 10 to 40 billion cubic feet (0.28 to 1.13 billion cubic metres), (
       <i>
        utvinnbar
       </i>
       ) of gas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WistingCentral_139-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WistingCentral-139">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Castberg_Oil_Field&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Castberg Oil Field (page does not exist)">
        Castberg Oil Field
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Castberg-feltet
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WistingCentral_139-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-WistingCentral-139">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       )—calculated size 540 million barrels of oil, and 2 to 7 billion cubic feet (57 to 198 million cubic metres) (
       <i>
        utvinnbar
       </i>
       ) of gas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Castberg-feltet_140-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Castberg-feltet-140">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Both oil fields are located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">
        Barents Sea
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Norway" title="Transport in Norway">
        Transport in Norway
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Norway" title="Rail transport in Norway">
        Rail transport in Norway
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Norway" title="List of airports in Norway">
        List of airports in Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg/220px-E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg/330px-E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg/440px-E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:E6_Brattlikollen_oktober_2015.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/European_route_E6" title="European route E6">
          E6
         </a>
         highway at Brattlikollen outskirts of
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
          Oslo
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Due to the low population density, narrow shape and long coastlines of Norway, its
       <a href="/wiki/Public_transport" title="Public transport">
        public transport
       </a>
       is less developed than in many European countries, especially outside the major cities. The country has long-standing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ship_transport" title="Ship transport">
        water transport
       </a>
       traditions, but the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Ministry_of_Transport_and_Communications" title="Norwegian Ministry of Transport and Communications">
        Norwegian Ministry of Transport and Communications
       </a>
       has in recent years implemented
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">
        rail
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Road_transport" title="Road transport">
        road
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Aviation" title="Aviation">
        air transport
       </a>
       through numerous subsidiaries to develop the country's infrastructure.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under discussion is development of a new high-speed rail system between the nation's largest cities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway's main railway network consists of 4,114 kilometres (2,556 mi) of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" title="Standard gauge">
        standard gauge
       </a>
       lines, of which 242 kilometres (150 mi) is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Double_track" title="Double track">
        double track
       </a>
       and 64 kilometres (40 mi)
       <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">
        high-speed rail
       </a>
       (210 km/h) while 62% is electrified at
       <a href="/wiki/15_kV_AC_railway_electrification" title="15 kV AC railway electrification">
        15 kV ​
        <span class="frac nowrap">
         16
         <span class="visualhide">
         </span>
         <sup>
          2
         </sup>
         ⁄
         <sub>
          3
         </sub>
        </span>
        Hz AC
       </a>
       . The railways transported 56,827,000 passengers 2,956 million
       <a href="/wiki/Units_of_transportation_measurement" title="Units of transportation measurement">
        passenger-kilometres
       </a>
       and 24,783,000 tonnes of cargo 3,414 million
       <a href="/wiki/Units_of_transportation_measurement" title="Units of transportation measurement">
        tonne-kilometres
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_144-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-144">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The entire network is owned by the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_National_Rail_Administration" title="Norwegian National Rail Administration">
        Norwegian National Rail Administration
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jbvabout_145-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-jbvabout-145">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All domestic passenger trains except the
       <a href="/wiki/Flytoget" title="Flytoget">
        Airport Express Train
       </a>
       are operated by
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_State_Railways" title="Norwegian State Railways">
        Norges Statsbaner
       </a>
       (NSB).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_146-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-146">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Several companies operate freight trains.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-administration1_147-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-administration1-147">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Investment in new infrastructure and maintenance is financed through the
       <a href="/wiki/State_budget_of_Norway" title="State budget of Norway">
        state budget
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jbvabout_145-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-jbvabout-145">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and subsidies are provided for passenger train operations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minpt_148-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-minpt-148">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       NSB operates long-haul trains, including
       <a href="/wiki/NSB_Night_Train" title="NSB Night Train">
        night trains
       </a>
       , regional services and four
       <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">
        commuter train
       </a>
       systems, around
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Commuter_Rail" title="Oslo Commuter Rail">
        Oslo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%B8ndelag_Commuter_Rail" title="Trøndelag Commuter Rail">
        Trondheim
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bergen_Commuter_Rail" title="Bergen Commuter Rail">
        Bergen
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A6ren_Line" title="Jæren Line">
        Stavanger
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2481" data-file-width="4961" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg/220px-Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg/330px-Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg/440px-Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oslo_Lufthavn_2017_-_visualisering_luftperspektiv_dag.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Visualization of
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Airport,_Gardermoen" title="Oslo Airport, Gardermoen">
          Oslo Airport, Gardermoen
         </a>
         as of 2017 after the latest expansion and renovation
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway has approximately 92,946 kilometres (57,754 mi) of
       <a href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">
        road
       </a>
       network, of which 72,033 kilometres (44,759 mi) are paved and 664 kilometres (413 mi) are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motorway" title="Motorway">
        motorway
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_65-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The four tiers of road routes are national, county, municipal and private, with national and primary county roads numbered en route. The most important national routes are part of the
       <a href="/wiki/International_E-road_network" title="International E-road network">
        European route
       </a>
       scheme. The two most prominent are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_route_E06" title="European route E06">
        E6
       </a>
       going north-south through the entire country, and the
       <a href="/wiki/European_route_E39" title="European route E39">
        E39
       </a>
       , which follows the West Coast. National and county roads are managed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Public_Roads_Administration" title="Norwegian Public Roads Administration">
        Norwegian Public Roads Administration
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway has the world's largest registered stock of
       <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicles_in_Norway" title="Plug-in electric vehicles in Norway">
        plug-in electric vehicles per capita
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwayLargest_151-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwayLargest-151">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AVERE_152-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AVERE-152">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwaySales2011_153-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwaySales2011-153">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2014, Norway became the first country where over 1 in every 100 passenger cars on the roads is a plug-in electric.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorwayEVSales032014_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorwayEVSales032014-154">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The plug-in electric segment
       <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">
        market share
       </a>
       of new car sales is also the highest in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top6Global2013_155-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Top6Global2013-155">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a report by
       <a href="/wiki/Dagens_N%C3%A6ringsliv" title="Dagens Næringsliv">
        Dagens Næringsliv
       </a>
       in June 2016, the country would like to ban all gasoline and diesel powered vehicles as early as 2025.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2017, 42% of new cars registered were electric.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Of the 97 airports in Norway,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_65-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       52 are public,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avinorpassengers_158-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-avinorpassengers-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 46 are operated by the state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Avinor" title="Avinor">
        Avinor
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_airports_in_the_Nordic_countries" title="List of the largest airports in the Nordic countries">
        Seven airports
       </a>
       have more than one million passengers annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avinorpassengers_158-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-avinorpassengers-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A total of 41,089,675 passengers passed through Norwegian airports in 2007, of whom 13,397,458 were international.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avinorpassengers_158-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-avinorpassengers-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The central gateway to Norway by air is
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Airport,_Gardermoen" title="Oslo Airport, Gardermoen">
        Oslo Airport, Gardermoen
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avinorpassengers_158-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-avinorpassengers-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Located about 35 kilometres (22 mi) northeast of Oslo, it is
       <a href="/wiki/Airline_hub" title="Airline hub">
        hub
       </a>
       for the two major Norwegian
       <a href="/wiki/Airline" title="Airline">
        airlines
       </a>
       :
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines" title="Scandinavian Airlines">
        Scandinavian Airlines
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Air_Shuttle" title="Norwegian Air Shuttle">
        Norwegian Air Shuttle
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and for regional aircraft from Western Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wideroemap_162-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wideroemap-162">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are departures to most European countries and some intercontinental destinations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A direct high-speed train connects to Oslo Central Station every 10 minutes for a 20 min ride.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Norway" title="Demographics of Norway">
        Demographics of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6339" data-file-width="5006" height="279" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg/220px-N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg/330px-N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg/440px-N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:N%C3%A6r%C3%B8ydalen_-_no-nb_digifoto_20150121_00098_NB_MIT_FNR_19592.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_people" title="Norwegian people">
          Ethnic
         </a>
         woman in Norwegian local geographic environment at
         <a href="/wiki/Voss" title="Voss">
          Voss
         </a>
         near
         <a href="/wiki/Gudvangen" title="Gudvangen">
          Gudvangen
         </a>
         in 1959
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="583" data-file-width="974" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG/300px-Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG/450px-Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG/600px-Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basic_demographics_of_Norway_1900_2000.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Demographics in Norway
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0 0 1em 1em;">

        </th>

        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>
       </tr>

        </th>

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

        </th>

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">

        </td>

        </th>

        </td>

        </td>
       </tr>
