         <small>
          (projected)
         </small>
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         7,032,687
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +0.69%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">
         <b>
          Source
         </b>
         :
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.ssb.no/fob2001/nos_d316/" rel="nofollow">
          Statistics Norway
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
          <a href="#cite_note-165">
           [164]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
          <a href="#cite_note-166">
           [165]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Norway's population was 5,096,300 people in October 2013.
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegians" title="Norwegians">
        Norwegians
       </a>
       are an ethnic North
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">
        Germanic
       </a>
       people. Since the late 20th century, Norway has attracted immigrants from southern and central Europe, the Mideast, Africa, Asia and beyond.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2012, an official study showed that 86%
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssb.no_167-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ssb.no-167">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of the total population have at least one parent who was born in Norway. More than 710,000 individuals (14%)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_168-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-168">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       are immigrants and their descendants; there are 117,000 children of immigrants, born in Norway.
      </p>
      <p>
       Of these 710,000 immigrants and their descendants:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        323,000 (39%)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_168-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-168">
          [167]
         </a>
        </sup>
        have a
        <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
         Western
        </a>
        background (Australia,
        <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">
         North America
        </a>
        , elsewhere in Europe)
       </li>
       <li>
        505,000 (61%)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_168-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-168">
          [167]
         </a>
        </sup>
        have a non-Western background (primarily
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moroccan_people" title="Moroccan people">
         Morocco
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iraqi_people" title="Iraqi people">
         Iraq
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_Kurdistan" title="Iraqi Kurdistan">
         Kurdistan federal region
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Somali_people" title="Somali people">
         Somalia
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pakistani_people" title="Pakistani people">
         Pakistan
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_people" title="Iranian people">
         Iran
        </a>
        including
        <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Province" title="Kurdistan Province">
         Kurdistan province
        </a>
        ).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       In 2013, the Norwegian government said that 14% of the Norwegian population were immigrants or children of two immigrant parents. About 6% of the immigrant population come from EU, North America and Australia, and about 8.1% come from Asia, Africa and Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssb13_169-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ssb13-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2012, of the total 660,000 with immigrant background, 407,262 had Norwegian citizenship (62.2%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SN2_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SN2-170">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Immigrants have settled in all
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_people" title="Norwegian people">
        Norwegian
       </a>
       municipalities. The cities or municipalities with the highest share of immigrants in 2012 were
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
        Oslo
       </a>
       (32%) and
       <a href="/wiki/Drammen" title="Drammen">
        Drammen
       </a>
       (27%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-innvbef_171-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-innvbef-171">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The share in Stavanger was 16%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-innvbef_171-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-innvbef-171">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">
        Reuters
       </a>
       , Oslo is the "fastest growing city in Europe because of increased immigration".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In recent years,
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">
        immigration
       </a>
       has accounted for most of Norway's population growth. In 2011, 16% of newborn children were of immigrant background.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_people" title="Sami people">
        Sami people
       </a>
       are
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">
        indigenous
       </a>
       to the Far North and have traditionally inhabited central and northern parts of Norway and Sweden, as well as areas in northern Finland and in Russia on the
       <a href="/wiki/Kola_Peninsula" title="Kola Peninsula">
        Kola Peninsula
       </a>
       . Another national minority are the
       <a href="/wiki/Kven_people" title="Kven people">
        Kven people
       </a>
       , descendants of Finnish-speaking people who migrated to northern Norway from the 18th up to the 20th century. From the 19th century up to the 1970s, the Norwegian government tried to assimilate both the Sami and the Kven, encouraging them to adopt the majority language, culture and religion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of this "
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegianization" title="Norwegianization">
        Norwegianization
       </a>
       process", many families of Sami or Kven ancestry now identify as ethnic Norwegian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">
        Migration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Migration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stpaul001.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="590" data-file-width="800" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Stpaul001.jpg/220px-Stpaul001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Stpaul001.jpg/330px-Stpaul001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Stpaul001.jpg/440px-Stpaul001.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stpaul001.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul" title="Minneapolis–Saint Paul">
          Minneapolis–Saint Paul
         </a>
         has the largest concentration of ethnic Norwegians outside Norway, at 470,000.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration">
        Emigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Emigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_diaspora" title="Norwegian diaspora">
        Norwegian diaspora
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Americans" title="Norwegian Americans">
        Norwegian Americans
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Particularly in the 19th century, when economic conditions were difficult in Norway, tens of thousands of people migrated to the United States and Canada, where they could work and buy land in frontier areas. Many went to the Midwest and Pacific Northwest. In 2006, according to the US Census Bureau, almost 4.7 million persons identified as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_American" title="Norwegian American">
        Norwegian Americans
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which was larger than the population of ethnic Norwegians in Norway itself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pop16_176-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pop16-176">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 2011 Canadian census, 452,705 Canadian citizens identified as having
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Canadian" title="Norwegian Canadian">
        Norwegian ancestry
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwegian_Canadians_177-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwegian_Canadians-177">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">
        Immigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Immigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Norway" title="Immigration to Norway">
        Immigration to Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 1 January 2013
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the number of immigrants or children of two immigrants residing in Norway was 710,465, or 14.1% of the total population,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssb13_169-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ssb13-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       up from 183,000 in 1992. Yearly immigration has increased since 2005. While yearly net immigration in 2001–2005 was on average 13,613, it increased to 37,541 between 2006 and 2010, and in 2011 net immigration reached 47,032.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is mostly because of increased immigration by residents of the EU, in particular from Poland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2012, the immigrant community (which includes immigrants and children born in Norway of immigrant parents) grew by 55,300, a record high.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssb13_169-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ssb13-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Net immigration from abroad reached 47,300 (300 higher than in 2011), while immigration accounted for 72% of Norway's population growth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       17% of newborn children were born to immigrant parents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssb13_169-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-ssb13-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Children of Pakistani, Somali and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Vietnamese" title="Norwegian Vietnamese">
        Vietnamese
       </a>
       parents made up the largest groups of all Norwegians born to immigrant parents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_181-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-census-181">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pakistani_Norwegians" title="Pakistani Norwegians">
        Pakistani Norwegians
       </a>
       are the largest non-European minority group in Norway. Most of their 32,700 members live in and around Oslo. The
       <a href="/wiki/Iraqis_in_Norway" title="Iraqis in Norway">
        Iraqi
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Somali_people" title="Somali people">
        Somali
       </a>
       immigrant populations have increased significantly in recent years. After the enlargement of the EU in 2004, a wave of immigrants has arrived from Central and Northern Europe, particularly
       <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
        Poland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">
        Lithuania
       </a>
       . The fastest growing immigrant groups in 2011 in absolute numbers were from
       <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
        Poland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">
        Lithuania
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ssb.no_182-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ssb.no-182">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The policies of immigration and integration have been the subject of much debate in Norway.
      </p>
      <p>
       Largest immigrant groups (1st and 2nd generation):
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_183-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-183">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <th>
         National background
        </th>
        <th>
         Population
        </th>
       </tr>

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>

         <span class="flagicon">

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-very_long" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           may be
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_size" title="Wikipedia:Article size">
            too long
           </a>
           to read and navigate comfortably
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please consider
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Splitting" title="Wikipedia:Splitting">
            splitting
           </a>
           content into sub-articles,
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">
            condensing
           </a>
           it, or adding or removing
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Section#Subsections" title="Help:Section">
            subheadings
           </a>
           .
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (January 2018)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Norway" title="Religion in Norway">
        Religion in Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nidaros_Cathedral,_Trondheim,_West_view_20150605_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4286" data-file-width="4260" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg/220px-Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg/330px-Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg/440px-Nidaros_Cathedral%2C_Trondheim%2C_West_view_20150605_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nidaros_Cathedral,_Trondheim,_West_view_20150605_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Nidaros_Cathedral" title="Nidaros Cathedral">
          Nidaros Cathedral
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">
          Trondheim
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stavechurch-heddal.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2840" data-file-width="3218" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Stavechurch-heddal.jpg/220px-Stavechurch-heddal.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Stavechurch-heddal.jpg/330px-Stavechurch-heddal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Stavechurch-heddal.jpg/440px-Stavechurch-heddal.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stavechurch-heddal.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Heddal_stave_church" title="Heddal stave church">
          Heddal stave church
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Notodden" title="Notodden">
          Notodden
         </a>
         , the largest
         <a href="/wiki/Stave_church" title="Stave church">
          stave church
         </a>
         in Norway
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2065" data-file-width="2755" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg/220px-2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg/330px-2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg/440px-2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2011-04-08_Bait-un-Nasr_mosque.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Baitun_Nasr_Mosque" title="Baitun Nasr Mosque">
          Baitun Nasr Mosque
         </a>
         on the outskirts of Oslo, the largest
         <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">
          mosque
         </a>
         in Norway
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
          <a href="#cite_note-184">
           [183]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most Norwegians are registered at baptism as members of the
       <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Norway" title="Church of Norway">
        Church of Norway
       </a>
       , which has been Norway's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_church" title="State church">
        state church
       </a>
       since its establishment. In recent years the church has been granted increasing internal autonomy, but it retains its special constitutional status and other special ties to the state, and the constitution requires that the reigning monarch must be a member and states that the country's values are based on its Christian and humanist heritage. Many remain in the church to participate in the community and practices such as
       <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">
        baptism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Confirmation" title="Confirmation">
        confirmation
       </a>
       , marriage and burial rites. About 71.5% of Norwegians were members of the Church of Norway in 2016. In 2016, about 55.3% of all newborns were baptised and about 60.0% of all 15-year-old persons were
       <a href="/wiki/Confirmation_(Lutheran_Church)" title="Confirmation (Lutheran Church)">
        confirmed
       </a>
       in the church.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the early 1990s, studies estimated that between 4.7% and 5.3% of Norwegians attended church on a weekly basis.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This figure has dropped to about 2%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2010, 10% of the population was
       <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
        religiously unaffiliated
       </a>
       , while another 9%, were members of religious communities outside the Church of Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norway1_189-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norway1-189">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christian
       </a>
       denominations total about 4.9%
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norway1_189-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norway1-189">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of the population, the largest of which is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">
        Roman Catholic Church
       </a>
       , with 83,000 members, according to 2009 government statistics.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An article in the newspaper
       <i>
        Aftenposten
       </i>
       in October 2012 noted there were about 115,234 registered Roman Catholics in Norway; the reporter estimated that the total number of people with a Roman Catholic background may be 170,000–200,000 or higher.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Others include
       <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">
        Pentecostals
       </a>
       (39,600),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Free_Church_of_Norway" title="Evangelical Lutheran Free Church of Norway">
        Evangelical Lutheran Free Church of Norway
       </a>
       (19,600),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodists" title="Methodists">
        Methodists
       </a>
       (11,000),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">
        Baptists
       </a>
       (9,900),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">
        Eastern Orthodox
       </a>
       (9,900),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Brunstad_Christian_Church" title="Brunstad Christian Church">
        Brunstad Christian Church
       </a>
       (6,800),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventists" title="Seventh-day Adventists">
        Seventh-day Adventists
       </a>
       (5,100),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Iraq#Christianity" title="Religion in Iraq">
        Assyrians and Chaldeans
       </a>
       , and others. The Swedish, Finnish and Icelandic Lutheran congregations in Norway have about 27,500 members in total.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other Christian denominations comprise less than 1% each, including 4,000 members in
       <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">
        The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
       </a>
       and 12,000
       <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
        Jehovah's Witnesses
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion2_190-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion2-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Among non-Christian religions,
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Norway" title="Islam in Norway">
        Islam
       </a>
       is the largest, with 132,135 registered members (2014), and probably fewer than 200,000 in total.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-192">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is practised mainly by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Somali_people" title="Somali people">
        Somali
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">
        Arab
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">
        Bosniak
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">
        Albanian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
        Turkish
       </a>
       immigrants, as well as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pakistani_Norwegians" title="Pakistani Norwegians">
        Norwegians of Pakistani descent
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Other religions comprise less than 1% each, including 819 adherents of
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Norway" title="History of the Jews in Norway">
        Judaism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion_193-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion-193">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">
        Indian
       </a>
       immigrants introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">
        Hinduism
       </a>
       to Norway, which in 2011 has slightly more than 5,900 adherents, or 1% of non-Lutheran Norwegians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion_193-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion-193">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">
        Sikhism
       </a>
       has approximately 3,000 adherents, with most living in Oslo, which has two
       <a href="/wiki/Gurdwara" title="Gurdwara">
        gurdwaras
       </a>
       . Sikhs first came to Norway in the early 1970s. The troubles in Punjab after
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Blue_Star" title="Operation Blue Star">
        Operation Blue Star
       </a>
       and riots committed against Sikhs in India after the
       <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi" title="Assassination of Indira Gandhi">
        assassination of Indira Gandhi
       </a>
       led to an increase in Sikh refugees moving to Norway. Drammen also has a sizeable population of Sikhs; the largest gurdwara in north Europe was built in
       <a href="/wiki/Lier,_Norway" title="Lier, Norway">
        Lier
       </a>
       . There are eleven
       <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
        Buddhist
       </a>
       organisations, grouped under the
       <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Federation_of_Norway" title="Buddhist Federation of Norway">
        Buddhistforbundet
       </a>
       organisation, with slightly over 14,000 members,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion_193-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion-193">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which make up 0.2% of the population. The
       <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">
        Baha'i
       </a>
       religion has slightly more than 1,000 adherents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwayreligion_193-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Norwayreligion-193">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Around 1.7% (84,500) of Norwegians belong to the secular
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Humanist_Association" title="Norwegian Humanist Association">
        Norwegian Humanist Association
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       From 2006 to 2011, the fastest-growing religious faith in Norway was
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodoxy_in_Norway" title="Orthodoxy in Norway">
        Orthodox Christianity
       </a>
       , which grew in membership by 80%; however, its share of the total population remains small, at 0.2%. It is associated with the huge immigration from
       <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">
        Eritrea
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">
        Ethiopia
       </a>
       , and to a lesser extent from
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">
        Eastern European
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
        Middle Eastern
       </a>
       countries. Other fast-growing religions were the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Norway" title="Roman Catholicism in Norway">
        Roman Catholic Church
       </a>
       (78.7%),
       <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Norway" title="Hinduism in Norway">
        Hinduism
       </a>
       (59.6%),
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Norway" title="Islam in Norway">
        Islam
       </a>
       (48.1%), and
       <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Norway" title="Buddhism in Norway">
        Buddhism
       </a>
       (46.7%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As in other
       <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">
        Scandinavian
       </a>
       countries, the ancient Norse followed a form of native
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Germanic_paganism" title="Germanic paganism">
        Germanic paganism
       </a>
       known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norse_paganism" title="Norse paganism">
        Norse paganism
       </a>
       . By the end of the 11th century, when Norway had been
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Scandinavia" title="Christianization of Scandinavia">
        Christianised
       </a>
       , the indigenous Norse religion and practices were prohibited. Remnants of the native religion and beliefs of Norway survive today in the form of names, referential names of cities and locations, the days of the week, and other parts of everyday language. Modern interest in the old ways has led to a revival of pagan religious practices in the form of
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Germanic_Neopaganism" title="Germanic Neopaganism">
         Åsatru
        </a>
        .
       </i>
       The Norwegian
       <i>
        Åsatrufellesskapet Bifrost
       </i>
       formed in 1996; in 2011, the fellowship had about 300 members.
       <i>
        Foreningen Forn Sed
       </i>
       was formed in 1999 and has been recognised by the Norwegian government.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Sami minority retained their
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_shamanism" title="Sami shamanism">
        shamanistic religion
       </a>
       well into the 18th century, when most converted to Christianity under the influence of Dano-Norwegian Lutheran
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Missionaries" title="Missionaries">
        missionaries
       </a>
       . Although some insist that "indigenous Sami religion had effectively been eradicated,'
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       athropologist
       <a href="/wiki/Gutorm_Gjessing" title="Gutorm Gjessing">
        Gutorm Gjessing
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        Changing Lapps
       </i>
       (1954) argues that the Samis "were outwardly and to all practical purposes converted to Christianity, but at the subconscious and unconscious level, the shamistic frenzy survived, more or less latent, only awaiting the necessary stimulus to break out into the open."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today there is a renewed appreciation for the Sami traditional way of life, which has led to a revival of
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Noaidevuohta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Noaidevuohta (page does not exist)">
         Noaidevuohta
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some Norwegian and Sami celebrities are reported to visit
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shamans" title="Shamans">
        shamans
       </a>
       for guidance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the 2010 Eurobarometer Poll, 22% of Norwegian citizens responded that "they believe there is a God", 44% responded that "they believe there is some sort of spirit or life force" and 29% responded that "they don't believe there is any sort of spirit, God or life force". Five percent gave no response.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eurobarometer_2010_200-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-eurobarometer_2010-200">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities_of_Norway">
        Largest cities of Norway
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Largest cities of Norway">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="navbox">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
         <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
         </div>
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_cities_of_Norway" title="Template:Largest cities of Norway">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_cities_of_Norway" title="Template talk:Largest cities of Norway">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">

             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Norway&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
          <span style="font-size:110%;">
           Largest cities or towns in Norway
          </span>
          <br/>
          <span style="font-weight:normal;">
           According to
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.ssb.no/en/befolkning/statistikker/beftett/aar/2014-07-01?fane=tabell&amp;sort=nummer&amp;tabell=186162" rel="nofollow">
            Statistics 2016
           </a>
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>

         </a>
        </th>

       </tr>

         </a>
         <br/>

         </a>
        </td>

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Moss,_Norway" title="Moss, Norway">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">

        </td>
        <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg" title="Stavanger/Sandnes">
          <img alt="Stavanger/Sandnes" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg/120px-Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg/180px-Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg/240px-Stavanger_sett_fra_fly.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Stavanger/Sandnes" title="Stavanger/Sandnes">
          Stavanger/Sandnes
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg" title="Trondheim">
          <img alt="Trondheim" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="857" data-file-width="1280" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg/120px-Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg/180px-Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg/240px-Overview_of_Trondheim_2008_03.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">

         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">

         </a>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         177,617
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         14
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Arendal" title="Arendal">

         </a>
        </td>

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         42,788
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         5
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Drammen" title="Drammen">
          Drammen
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Buskerud" title="Buskerud">
          Buskerud
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         115,137
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         15
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Bod%C3%B8" title="Bodø">
          Bodø
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Nordland" title="Nordland">
          Nordland
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         40,209
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         6
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Fredrikstad/Sarpsborg" title="Fredrikstad/Sarpsborg">

         </a>
        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/%C3%98stfold" title="Østfold">
          Østfold
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         109,907
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

       </tr>

         26,828
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         8
        </td>

        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Vest-Agder" title="Vest-Agder">

        </td>

        </td>

         </a>

       </tr>
       <tr>

        </td>

      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Norway" title="Education in Norway">
        Education in Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg/220px-NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg/330px-NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg/440px-NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NTNU_Trondheim_Mainbuilding.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The main building of the
         <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Norwegian University of Science and Technology">
          Norwegian University of Science and Technology
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">
          Trondheim
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Norway" title="Higher education in Norway">
        Higher education in Norway
       </a>
       is offered by a range of seven
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Norway" title="List of universities in Norway">
        universities
       </a>
       , five specialised colleges, 25
       <a href="/wiki/University_college" title="University college">
        university colleges
       </a>
       as well as a range of private colleges. Education follows the
       <a href="/wiki/Bologna_Process" title="Bologna Process">
        Bologna Process
       </a>
       involving
       <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">
        Bachelor
       </a>
       (3 years),
       <a href="/wiki/Master%27s_degree" title="Master's degree">
        Master
       </a>
       (2 years) and
       <a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy" title="Doctor of Philosophy">
        PhD
       </a>
       (3 years) degrees.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Acceptance is offered after finishing
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Norway" title="Education in Norway">
        upper secondary school
       </a>
       with general study competence.
      </p>
      <p>
       Public education is virtually free, regardless of nationality.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The academic year has two
       <a href="/wiki/Academic_term" title="Academic term">
        semesters
       </a>
       , from August to December and from January to June. The ultimate responsibility for the education lies with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Ministry_of_Education_and_Research" title="Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research">
        Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Norway" title="Languages of Norway">
        Languages of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">
        Norwegian language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_languages" title="Sami languages">
        Sami languages
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Norwegian_dialects.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1856" data-file-width="1405" height="291" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Norwegian_dialects.PNG/220px-Norwegian_dialects.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Norwegian_dialects.PNG/330px-Norwegian_dialects.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Norwegian_dialects.PNG/440px-Norwegian_dialects.PNG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Norwegian_dialects.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Distribution of Norwegian dialect groups: North Norwegian (yellow), Trøndelag Norwegian (navy blue), West Norwegian (orange) and East Norwegian (pale blue).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norwegian and Sami are the two official languages of Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/North_Germanic_languages" title="North Germanic languages">
        North Germanic
       </a>
       Norwegian language has two official written forms,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Bokm%C3%A5l" title="Bokmål">
         Bokmål
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Nynorsk" title="Nynorsk">
         Nynorsk
        </a>
       </i>
       . Both are used in public administration, schools, churches, and media. Bokmål is the written language used by a large majority of about 80–85%. Around 95% of the population speak Norwegian as their first or native language, although many speak
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">
        dialects
       </a>
       that may differ significantly from the written languages. All Norwegian dialects are mutually intelligible, although listeners with limited exposure to dialects other than their own may struggle to understand certain phrases and pronunciations in some other dialects.
      </p>
      <p>
       Several
       <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">
        Uralic
       </a>
       Sami languages are spoken and written throughout the country, especially in the north, by some members of the Sami people. (Estimates suggest that about one third of the Norwegian Sami speak a Sami language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ) Speakers have a right to be educated and to receive communication from the government in their own language in a special
       <i>
        forvaltningsområde
       </i>
       (administrative area) for Sami languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Kven_people" title="Kven people">
        Kven
       </a>
       minority historically spoke the Uralic
       <a href="/wiki/Kven_language" title="Kven language">
        Kven language
       </a>
       (considered a separate language in Norway, but generally perceived as a Finnish dialect in Finland). Today the majority of ethnic Kven have little or no knowledge of the language. According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Kainun_institutti" title="Kainun institutti">
        Kainun institutti
       </a>
       , "The typical modern Kven is a Norwegian-speaking Norwegian who knows his genealogy."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As Norway has ratified the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">
        European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages
       </a>
       (ECRML) the Kven language together with
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
        Romani
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Scandoromani_language" title="Scandoromani language">
        Scandoromani language
       </a>
       has become officially recognised minority languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some supporters have also advocated making
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Sign_Language" title="Norwegian Sign Language">
        Norwegian Sign Language
       </a>
       an official language of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 19th and 20th centuries, the Norwegian language was subject to
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language_conflict" title="Norwegian language conflict">
        strong political and cultural controversies
       </a>
       . This led to the development of Nynorsk in the 19th century and to the formation of alternative spelling standards in the 20th century.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norwegian is similar to the other languages in Scandinavia:
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">
        Swedish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">
        Danish
       </a>
       . All three languages are to a degree mutually intelligible and can be, and commonly are, employed in communication among inhabitants of the Scandinavian countries. As a result of the co-operation within the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council" title="Nordic Council">
        Nordic Council
       </a>
       , inhabitants of all Nordic countries, including
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       , have the right to communicate with Norwegian authorities in their own language.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Students who are children of immigrant parents are encouraged to learn the Norwegian language. The Norwegian government offers language instructional courses for immigrants wishing to obtain Norwegian citizenship. With increasing concern about assimilating immigrants, since 1 September 2008, the government has required that an applicant for Norwegian citizenship give evidence of proficiency in either Norwegian or in one of the Sami languages, or give proof of having attended classes in Norwegian for 300 hours, or meet the language requirements for university studies in Norway (that is, by being proficient in one of the Scandinavian languages).
      </p>
      <p>
       The primary foreign language taught in Norwegian schools is
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       , considered an international language since the post-WWII era. The majority of the population is fairly fluent in English, especially those born after World War II.
       <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
        German
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       are also commonly taught as second or, more often, third languages.
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">
        Russian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">
        Japanese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       , and rarely
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Mandarin" title="Standard Mandarin">
        Chinese (Mandarin)
       </a>
       are offered in some schools, mostly in the cities. Traditionally, English, German and French were considered the main foreign languages in Norway. These languages, for instance, were used on
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_passport" title="Norwegian passport">
        Norwegian passports
       </a>
       until the 1990s, and university students have a general right to use these languages when submitting their theses.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Norway" title="Culture of Norway">
        Culture of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bryggen,_Bergen3.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1696" data-file-width="2544" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG/220px-Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG/330px-Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG/440px-Bryggen%2C_Bergen3.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bryggen,_Bergen3.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bryggen" title="Bryggen">
          Bryggen
         </a>
         in Bergen is on the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Europe" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Europe">
          list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Norwegian
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Farm_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Farm culture (page does not exist)">
        farm culture
       </a>
       continues to play a role in contemporary Norwegian culture. In the 19th century, it inspired a strong
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_romantic_nationalism" title="Norwegian romantic nationalism">
        romantic nationalistic
       </a>
       movement, which is still visible in the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">
        Norwegian language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Category:Media_in_Norway" title="Category:Media in Norway">
        media
       </a>
       . Norwegian culture blossomed with nationalist efforts to achieve an independent identity in the areas of literature, art and music. This continues today in the performing arts and as a result of government support for exhibitions, cultural projects and artwork.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wilhelmine_Seippel.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="380" data-file-width="298" height="281" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Wilhelmine_Seippel.jpg/220px-Wilhelmine_Seippel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c7/Wilhelmine_Seippel.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wilhelmine_Seippel.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Traditional Norwegian farmer's costumes, known as
         <i>
          folkedrakt
         </i>
         , and modern costumes inspired by those costumes, known as
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Bunad" title="Bunad">
           bunad
          </a>
         </i>
         , are widely used on special occasions.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">
        Human rights
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Human rights">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Norway has been considered a progressive country, which has adopted legislation and policies to support women's rights, minority rights, and
       <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Norway" title="LGBT rights in Norway">
        LGBT rights
       </a>
       . As early as 1884, 171 of the leading figures, among them five Prime Ministers for the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party, co-founded the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Association_for_Women%27s_Rights" title="Norwegian Association for Women's Rights">
        Norwegian Association for Women's Rights
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They successfully campaigned for women's
       <a href="/wiki/Right_to_education" title="Right to education">
        right to education
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women's suffrage">
        women's suffrage
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Right_to_work" title="Right to work">
        right to work
       </a>
       , and other gender equality policies. From the 1970s, gender equality also came high on the state agenda, with the establishment of a public body to promote gender equality, which evolved into the
       <a href="/wiki/Gender_Equality_and_Anti-Discrimination_Ombud" title="Gender Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud">
        Gender Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud
       </a>
       . Civil society organisations also continue to play an important role, and the women's rights organisations are today organised in the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Women%27s_Lobby" title="Norwegian Women's Lobby">
        Norwegian Women's Lobby
       </a>
       umbrella organisation.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1990, the Norwegian constitution was amended to grant
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Absolute_primogeniture" title="Absolute primogeniture">
        absolute primogeniture
       </a>
       to the Norwegian throne, meaning that the eldest child, regardless of gender, takes precedence in the line of succession. As it was not retroactive, the current successor to the throne is the eldest son of the King, rather than his eldest child. The Norwegian constitution Article 6 states that "For those born before the year 1990 it shall...be the case that a male shall take precedence over a female."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Sami people have for centuries been the subject of discrimination and abuse by the dominant cultures in Scandinavia and Russia, those countries claiming possession of Sami lands.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Sami people have never been a single community in a single region of
       <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A1pmi" title="Sápmi">
        Lapland
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Norway has been greatly criticised by the international community for the politics of
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegianization" title="Norwegianization">
        Norwegianization
       </a>
       of and discrimination against the indigenous population of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nevertheless, Norway was, in 1990, the first country to recognise
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_and_Tribal_Peoples_Convention,_1989" title="Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989">
        ILO-convention 169
       </a>
       on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indigenous_people" title="Indigenous people">
        indigenous people
       </a>
       recommended by the UN.
      </p>
      <p>
       In regard to LGBT rights, Norway was the first country in the world to enact an anti-discrimination law protecting the rights of gays and lesbians. In 1993, Norway became the second country to legalise
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_union" title="Civil union">
        civil union
       </a>
       partnerships for same-sex couples, and on 1 January 2009
       <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_Norway" title="Same-sex marriage in Norway">
        Norway became the sixth country
       </a>
       to grant full
       <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">
        marriage equality
       </a>
       to same-sex couples. As a promoter of human rights, Norway has held the annual
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Freedom_Forum" title="Oslo Freedom Forum">
        Oslo Freedom Forum
       </a>
       conference, a gathering described by
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">
         The Economist
        </a>
       </i>
       as "on its way to becoming a human-rights equivalent of the Davos economic forum."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion_2">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state#Norway" title="Separation of church and state">
        Separation of church and state
       </a>
       happened significantly later in Norway than in most of Europe and is not yet complete. In 2012, the Norwegian parliament voted to grant the
       <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Norway" title="Church of Norway">
        Church of Norway
       </a>
       greater autonomy,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       a decision which was confirmed in a constitutional amendment on 21 May 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Until 2012 parliamentary officials were required to be members of the Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Norway, and at least half of all government ministers had to be a member of the state church. As state church, the Church of Norway's clergy were viewed are state employees, and the central and regional church administrations were part of the state administration. Members of the Royal family are required to be members of the Lutheran church. On 1 January 2017, Norway made the church independent of the state, but retained the Church's status as the «people’s church».
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">
        Cinema
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Cinema">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Norway" title="Cinema of Norway">
        Cinema of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Norwegian cinema has received international recognition. The documentary film
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kon-Tiki_(1950_film)" title="Kon-Tiki (1950 film)">
         Kon-Tiki
        </a>
       </i>
       (1950) of the expedition won an American Oscar
       <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">
        Academy Award
       </a>
       . In 1959,
       <a href="/wiki/Arne_Skouen" title="Arne Skouen">
        Arne Skouen
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        Nine Lives
       </i>
       was nominated, but failed to win. Another notable film is
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Pinchcliffe_Grand_Prix" title="The Pinchcliffe Grand Prix">
         Flåklypa Grand Prix
        </a>
       </i>
       (English:
       <i>
        Pinchcliffe Grand Prix
       </i>
       ), an animated feature film directed by
       <a href="/wiki/Ivo_Caprino" title="Ivo Caprino">
        Ivo Caprino
       </a>
       . The film was released in 1975 and is based on characters from Norwegian cartoonist
       <a href="/wiki/Kjell_Aukrust" title="Kjell Aukrust">
        Kjell Aukrust
       </a>
       . It is the most widely seen Norwegian film of all time.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Nils_Gaup" title="Nils Gaup">
        Nils Gaup
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Pathfinder_(1987_film)" title="Pathfinder (1987 film)">
         Pathfinder
        </a>
       </i>
       (1987), the story of the
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_people" title="Sami people">
        Sami
       </a>
       , was nominated for an Oscar.
       <a href="/wiki/Berit_Nesheim" title="Berit Nesheim">
        Berit Nesheim
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Other_Side_of_Sunday" title="The Other Side of Sunday">
         The Other Side of Sunday
        </a>
       </i>
       was nominated for an Oscar in 1997.
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the 1990s, the film industry has thrived, producing up to 20 feature films each year. Particular successes were
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kristin_Lavransdatter" title="Kristin Lavransdatter">
         Kristin Lavransdatter
        </a>
       </i>
       , based on a novel by a Nobel Prize winner;
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Telegraphist" title="The Telegraphist">
         The Telegraphist
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gurin_with_the_Foxtail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gurin with the Foxtail (page does not exist)">
         Gurin with the Foxtail
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Knut_Erik_Jensen" title="Knut Erik Jensen">
        Knut Erik Jensen
       </a>
       was among the more successful new directors, together with
       <a href="/wiki/Erik_Skjoldbj%C3%A6rg" title="Erik Skjoldbjærg">
        Erik Skjoldbjærg
       </a>
       , who is remembered for
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Insomnia_(1997_film)" title="Insomnia (1997 film)">
         Insomnia
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The country has also been used as filming location for several Hollywood and other international productions, including
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back" title="The Empire Strikes Back">
         The Empire Strikes Back
        </a>
       </i>
       (1980), for which the producers used
       <a href="/wiki/Hardangerj%C3%B8kulen" title="Hardangerjøkulen">
        Hardangerjøkulen
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">
        glacier
       </a>
       as a filming location for scenes of the ice planet Hoth. It included a memorable battle in the snow. The films
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Die_Another_Day" title="Die Another Day">
         Die Another Day
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Golden_Compass_(film)" title="The Golden Compass (film)">
         The Golden Compass
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Spies_Like_Us" title="Spies Like Us">
         Spies Like Us
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Heroes_of_Telemark" title="The Heroes of Telemark">
         Heroes of Telemark
        </a>
        ,
       </i>
       as well as the TV series
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lilyhammer" title="Lilyhammer">
         Lilyhammer
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Vikings_(2013_TV_series)" title="Vikings (2013 TV series)">
         Vikings
        </a>
       </i>
       also had scenes set in Norway.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A short film,
       <i>
        The Spirit of Norway
       </i>
       was featured at
       <a href="/wiki/Maelstrom_(ride)" title="Maelstrom (ride)">
        Maelstrom
       </a>
       at
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norway_(Epcot)" title="Norway (Epcot)">
        Norway
       </a>
       Pavilion at
       <a href="/wiki/Epcot" title="Epcot">
        Epcot
       </a>
       located within
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort" title="Walt Disney World Resort">
        Walt Disney World Resort
       </a>
       in Florida in the United States. The attraction and the film ceased their operations on 5 October 2014.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Music">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Norway" title="Music of Norway">
        Music of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Edvard_Grieg_(1888)_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="863" data-file-width="567" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg/170px-Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg/255px-Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg/340px-Edvard_Grieg_%281888%29_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Edvard_Grieg_(1888)_by_Elliot_and_Fry_-_02.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Grieg" title="Edvard Grieg">
          Edvard Grieg
         </a>
         , composer and pianist
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The classical
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Norway" title="Music of Norway">
        music
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
        romantic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Composer" title="Composer">
        composers
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Grieg" title="Edvard Grieg">
        Edvard Grieg
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rikard_Nordraak" title="Rikard Nordraak">
        Rikard Nordraak
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Johan_Svendsen" title="Johan Svendsen">
        Johan Svendsen
       </a>
       is internationally known, as is the modern music of
       <a href="/wiki/Arne_Nordheim" title="Arne Nordheim">
        Arne Nordheim
       </a>
       . Norway's classical performers include
       <a href="/wiki/Leif_Ove_Andsnes" title="Leif Ove Andsnes">
        Leif Ove Andsnes
       </a>
       , one of the world's more famous pianists;
       <a href="/wiki/Truls_M%C3%B8rk" title="Truls Mørk">
        Truls Mørk
       </a>
       , an outstanding cellist; and the great Wagnerian soprano
       <a href="/wiki/Kirsten_Flagstad" title="Kirsten Flagstad">
        Kirsten Flagstad
       </a>
       .
      </p>
