      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Early_Norwegian_black_metal_scene" title="Early Norwegian black metal scene">
        Norwegian black metal
       </a>
       , a form of
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Norway" title="Rock music in Norway">
        rock music in Norway
       </a>
       , has been an influence in world music since the late 20th century. Since the 1990s, Norway's export of
       <a href="/wiki/Black_metal" title="Black metal">
        black metal
       </a>
       , a lo-fi, dark and raw form of
       <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">
        heavy metal
       </a>
       , has been developed by such bands as
       <a href="/wiki/Emperor_(band)" title="Emperor (band)">
        Emperor
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Darkthrone" title="Darkthrone">
        Darkthrone
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gorgoroth" title="Gorgoroth">
        Gorgoroth
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mayhem_(band)" title="Mayhem (band)">
        Mayhem
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Burzum" title="Burzum">
        Burzum
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Immortal_(band)" title="Immortal (band)">
        Immortal
       </a>
       . More recently bands such as
       <a href="/wiki/Enslaved_(band)" title="Enslaved (band)">
        Enslaved
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kvelertak" title="Kvelertak">
        Kvelertak
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dimmu_Borgir" title="Dimmu Borgir">
        Dimmu Borgir
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Satyricon" title="Satyricon">
        Satyricon
       </a>
       have evolved the genre into the present day while still garnering worldwide fans. Controversial events associated with the black metal movement in the early 1990s included several
       <a href="/wiki/Church_arson" title="Church arson">
        church burnings
       </a>
       and two prominent
       <a href="/wiki/Black_metal#Aarseth's_murder" title="Black metal">
        murder cases
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The jazz scene in Norway is thriving.
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Garbarek" title="Jan Garbarek">
        Jan Garbarek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Terje_Rypdal" title="Terje Rypdal">
        Terje Rypdal
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mari_Boine" title="Mari Boine">
        Mari Boine
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arild_Andersen" title="Arild Andersen">
        Arild Andersen
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Bugge_Wesseltoft" title="Bugge Wesseltoft">
        Bugge Wesseltoft
       </a>
       are internationally recognised while
       <a href="/wiki/Paal_Nilssen-Love" title="Paal Nilssen-Love">
        Paal Nilssen-Love
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Supersilent" title="Supersilent">
        Supersilent
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jaga_Jazzist" title="Jaga Jazzist">
        Jaga Jazzist
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Wibutee" title="Wibutee">
        Wibutee
       </a>
       are becoming world-class artists of the younger generation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FeleHel_(2).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1571" data-file-width="802" height="333" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/FeleHel_%282%29.jpg/170px-FeleHel_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/FeleHel_%282%29.jpg/255px-FeleHel_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/FeleHel_%282%29.jpg/340px-FeleHel_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FeleHel_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hardanger_fiddle" title="Hardanger fiddle">
          Hardingfele
         </a>
         , the "Hardanger fiddle", a Norwegian instrument
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Norway has a strong
       <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">
        folk music
       </a>
       tradition which remains popular to this day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among the most prominent folk musicians are
       <a href="/wiki/Hardanger_fiddle" title="Hardanger fiddle">
        Hardanger fiddlers
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Een" title="Andrea Een">
        Andrea Een
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olav_J%C3%B8rgen_Hegge" title="Olav Jørgen Hegge">
        Olav Jørgen Hegge
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Annbj%C3%B8rg_Lien" title="Annbjørg Lien">
        Annbjørg Lien
       </a>
       , and the vocalists
       <a href="/wiki/Agnes_Buen_Garn%C3%A5s" title="Agnes Buen Garnås">
        Agnes Buen Garnås
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kirsten_Br%C3%A5ten_Berg" title="Kirsten Bråten Berg">
        Kirsten Bråten Berg
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Odd_Nordstoga" title="Odd Nordstoga">
        Odd Nordstoga
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Other internationally recognised bands are
       <a href="/wiki/A-ha" title="A-ha">
        A-ha
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B6yksopp" title="Röyksopp">
        Röyksopp
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ylvis" title="Ylvis">
        Ylvis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A-ha initially rose to global fame during the mid-1980s. In the 1990s and 2000s, the group maintained its popularity domestically, and has remained successful outside Norway, especially in Germany, Switzerland, France, and Brazil.
      </p>
      <p>
       Some of the most memorable female solo artists from Norway are
       <a href="/wiki/Astrid_S" title="Astrid S">
        Astrid S
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Adel%C3%A9n" title="Adelén">
        Adelén
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Julie_Bergan" title="Julie Bergan">
        Julie Bergan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Mena" title="Maria Mena">
        Maria Mena
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tone_Damli" title="Tone Damli">
        Tone Damli
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Berger" title="Margaret Berger">
        Margaret Berger
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lene_Marlin" title="Lene Marlin">
        Lene Marlin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Christel_Alsos" title="Christel Alsos">
        Christel Alsos
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Arredondo" title="Maria Arredondo">
        Maria Arredondo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lene_Nystr%C3%B8m" title="Lene Nystrøm">
        Lene Nystrøm
       </a>
       vocalist of the popular Danish dance band
       <a href="/wiki/Aqua_(band)" title="Aqua (band)">
        Aqua
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Marion_Raven" title="Marion Raven">
        Marion Raven
       </a>
       &amp;
       <a href="/wiki/Marit_Larsen" title="Marit Larsen">
        Marit Larsen
       </a>
       both former members of the defunct pop-rock band
       <a href="/wiki/M2M_(band)" title="M2M (band)">
        M2M
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In recent years, various Norwegian songwriters and production teams have contributed to the music of other international artists. The Norwegian production team
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stargate_(production_team)" title="Stargate (production team)">
        Stargate
       </a>
       has produced songs for
       <a href="/wiki/Rihanna" title="Rihanna">
        Rihanna
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">
        Beyoncé
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
        Shakira
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Lopez" title="Jennifer Lopez">
        Jennifer Lopez
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">
        Lionel Richie
       </a>
       , among others.
       <a href="/wiki/Espen_Lind" title="Espen Lind">
        Espen Lind
       </a>
       has written and produced songs for Beyoncé, Lionel Richie and
       <a href="/wiki/Leona_Lewis" title="Leona Lewis">
        Leona Lewis
       </a>
       , among others.
       <a href="/wiki/Lene_Marlin" title="Lene Marlin">
        Lene Marlin
       </a>
       has written songs for Rihanna and
       <a href="/wiki/Lovebugs_(band)" title="Lovebugs (band)">
        Lovebugs
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Ina_Wroldsen" title="Ina Wroldsen">
        Ina Wroldsen
       </a>
       has written songs for artists such as
       <a href="/wiki/Demi_Lovato" title="Demi Lovato">
        Demi Lovato
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
        Shakira
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Inna" title="Inna">
        Inna
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sophie_Ellis-Bextor" title="Sophie Ellis-Bextor">
        Sophie Ellis-Bextor
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/One_Direction" title="One Direction">
        One Direction
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/The_Saturdays" title="The Saturdays">
        The Saturdays
       </a>
       among others.
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway enjoys many music festivals throughout the year, all over the country. Norway is the host of one of the world's biggest
       <a href="/wiki/Extreme_sport" title="Extreme sport">
        extreme sport
       </a>
       festivals with music,
       <a href="/wiki/Ekstremsportveko" title="Ekstremsportveko">
        Ekstremsportveko
       </a>
       —a festival held annually in
       <a href="/wiki/Voss" title="Voss">
        Voss
       </a>
       . Oslo is the host of many festivals, such as
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%98yafestivalen" title="Øyafestivalen">
        Øyafestivalen
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/By:Larm" title="By:Larm">
        by:Larm
       </a>
       . Oslo used to have a summer parade similar to the German
       <a href="/wiki/Love_Parade" title="Love Parade">
        Love Parade
       </a>
       . In 1992, the city of Oslo wanted to adopt the French music festival
       <i>
        Fête de la Musique
       </i>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Fredrik_Carl_St%C3%B8rmer" title="Fredrik Carl Størmer">
        Fredrik Carl Størmer
       </a>
       established the festival. Even in its first year, "Musikkens Dag" gathered thousands of people and artists in the streets of Oslo. "Musikkens Dag" is now renamed
       <i>
        Musikkfest Oslo
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Literature">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_literature" title="Norwegian literature">
        Norwegian literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Norwegian_writers" title="List of Norwegian writers">
        List of Norwegian writers
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3300" data-file-width="2328" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg/170px-Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg/255px-Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg/340px-Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hamsun_bldsa_HA0269.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Knut_Hamsun" title="Knut Hamsun">
          Knut Hamsun
         </a>
         , author
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The history of Norwegian literature starts with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norse_paganism" title="Norse paganism">
        pagan
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Poetic_Edda" title="Poetic Edda">
        Eddaic poems
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Skald" title="Skald">
        skaldic
       </a>
       verse of the 9th and 10th centuries, with poets such as
       <a href="/wiki/Bragi_Boddason" title="Bragi Boddason">
        Bragi Boddason
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eyvindr_sk%C3%A1ldaspillir" title="Eyvindr skáldaspillir">
        Eyvindr skáldaspillir
       </a>
       . The arrival of Christianity around the year 1000 brought Norway into contact with European mediaeval learning,
       <a href="/wiki/Hagiography" title="Hagiography">
        hagiography
       </a>
       and history writing. Merged with native oral tradition and Icelandic influence, this influenced the literature written in the late 12th and early 13th centuries. Major works of that period include
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Historia_Norwegi%C3%A6" title="Historia Norwegiæ">
         Historia Norwegiæ
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%9Ei%C3%B0rekssaga" title="Þiðrekssaga">
         Þiðrekssaga
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Konungs_skuggsj%C3%A1" title="Konungs skuggsjá">
         Konungs skuggsjá
        </a>
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Little Norwegian literature came out of the period of the Scandinavian Union and the subsequent Dano-Norwegian union (1387–1814), with some notable exceptions such as
       <a href="/wiki/Petter_Dass" title="Petter Dass">
        Petter Dass
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg" title="Ludvig Holberg">
        Ludvig Holberg
       </a>
       . In his play
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Peer_Gynt" title="Peer Gynt">
         Peer Gynt
        </a>
       </i>
       , Ibsen characterised this period as "Twice two hundred years of darkness/brooded o'er the race of monkeys." The first line of this couplet is frequently quoted. During the union with Denmark, the government imposed using only written Danish, which decreased the writing of Norwegian literature.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ibsen_photography.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1979" data-file-width="1375" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Ibsen_photography.jpg/170px-Ibsen_photography.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Ibsen_photography.jpg/255px-Ibsen_photography.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Ibsen_photography.jpg/340px-Ibsen_photography.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ibsen_photography.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen" title="Henrik Ibsen">
          Henrik Ibsen
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Two major events precipitated a major resurgence in Norwegian literature: in 1811 a Norwegian university was established in
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
        Christiania
       </a>
       . Secondly, seized by the spirit of revolution following the
       <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">
        American
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">
        French
       </a>
       revolutions, the Norwegians created their first
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Norway" title="Constitution of Norway">
        Constitution
       </a>
       in 1814. Strong authors were inspired who became recognised first in Scandinavia, and then worldwide; among them were
       <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Wergeland" title="Henrik Wergeland">
        Henrik Wergeland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Christen_Asbj%C3%B8rnsen" title="Peter Christen Asbjørnsen">
        Peter Christen Asbjørnsen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8rgen_Moe" title="Jørgen Moe">
        Jørgen Moe
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Camilla_Collett" title="Camilla Collett">
        Camilla Collett
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       By the late 19th century, in the
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age" title="Golden Age">
        Golden Age
       </a>
       of Norwegian literature, the so-called "Great Four" emerged:
       <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen" title="Henrik Ibsen">
        Henrik Ibsen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnstjerne_Bj%C3%B8rnson" title="Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson">
        Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Kielland" title="Alexander Kielland">
        Alexander Kielland
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Lie_(writer)" title="Jonas Lie (writer)">
        Jonas Lie
       </a>
       . Bjørnson's "peasant novels", such as
       <i>
        Ein glad gut
       </i>
       (A Happy Boy) and
       <i>
        Synnøve Solbakken
       </i>
       , are typical of the
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_romantic_nationalism" title="Norwegian romantic nationalism">
        Norwegian romantic nationalism
       </a>
       of their day. Kielland's novels and short stories are mostly naturalistic. Although an important contributor to early romantic nationalism, (especially
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Peer_Gynt" title="Peer Gynt">
         Peer Gynt
        </a>
       </i>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen" title="Henrik Ibsen">
        Henrik Ibsen
       </a>
       is better known for his pioneering realistic dramas such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Wild_Duck" title="The Wild Duck">
         The Wild Duck
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/A_Doll%27s_House" title="A Doll's House">
         A Doll's House
        </a>
        .
       </i>
       They caused an uproar because of his candid portrayals of the middle classes, complete with infidelity, unhappy marriages, and corrupt businessmen.
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 20th century, three Norwegian novelists were awarded the
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
        Nobel Prize in Literature
       </a>
       :
       <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnstjerne_Bj%C3%B8rnson" title="Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson">
        Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson
       </a>
       in 1903,
       <a href="/wiki/Knut_Hamsun" title="Knut Hamsun">
        Knut Hamsun
       </a>
       for the book
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Growth_of_the_Soil" title="Growth of the Soil">
         Markens grøde
        </a>
       </i>
       ("Growth of the Soil") in 1920, and
       <a href="/wiki/Sigrid_Undset" title="Sigrid Undset">
        Sigrid Undset
       </a>
       (known for
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kristin_Lavransdatter" title="Kristin Lavransdatter">
         Kristinlavransdatter
        </a>
       </i>
       ) in 1928. Writers such as the following also made important contributions:
       <a href="/wiki/Dag_Solstad" title="Dag Solstad">
        Dag Solstad
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jon_Fosse" title="Jon Fosse">
        Jon Fosse
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cora_Sandel" title="Cora Sandel">
        Cora Sandel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olav_Duun" title="Olav Duun">
        Olav Duun
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olav_H._Hauge" title="Olav H. Hauge">
        Olav H. Hauge
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gunvor_Hofmo" title="Gunvor Hofmo">
        Gunvor Hofmo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Stein_Mehren" title="Stein Mehren">
        Stein Mehren
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kjell_Askildsen" title="Kjell Askildsen">
        Kjell Askildsen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hans_Herbj%C3%B8rnsrud" title="Hans Herbjørnsrud">
        Hans Herbjørnsrud
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aksel_Sandemose" title="Aksel Sandemose">
        Aksel Sandemose
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bergljot_Hob%C3%A6k_Haff" title="Bergljot Hobæk Haff">
        Bergljot Hobæk Haff
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jostein_Gaarder" title="Jostein Gaarder">
        Jostein Gaarder
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Erik_Fosnes_Hansen" title="Erik Fosnes Hansen">
        Erik Fosnes Hansen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jens_Bj%C3%B8rneboe" title="Jens Bjørneboe">
        Jens Bjørneboe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kjartan_Fl%C3%B8gstad" title="Kjartan Fløgstad">
        Kjartan Fløgstad
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lars_Saabye_Christensen" title="Lars Saabye Christensen">
        Lars Saabye Christensen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Johan_Borgen" title="Johan Borgen">
        Johan Borgen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Herbj%C3%B8rg_Wassmo" title="Herbjørg Wassmo">
        Herbjørg Wassmo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Erik_Vold" title="Jan Erik Vold">
        Jan Erik Vold
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rolf_Jacobsen_(poet)" title="Rolf Jacobsen (poet)">
        Rolf Jacobsen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olaf_Bull" title="Olaf Bull">
        Olaf Bull
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jan_Kj%C3%A6rstad" title="Jan Kjærstad">
        Jan Kjærstad
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Georg_Johannesen" title="Georg Johannesen">
        Georg Johannesen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tarjei_Vesaas" title="Tarjei Vesaas">
        Tarjei Vesaas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sigurd_Hoel" title="Sigurd Hoel">
        Sigurd Hoel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arnulf_%C3%98verland" title="Arnulf Øverland">
        Arnulf Øverland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Karl_Ove_Knausg%C3%A5rd" title="Karl Ove Knausgård">
        Karl Ove Knausgård
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Johan_Falkberget" title="Johan Falkberget">
        Johan Falkberget
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Research">
        Research
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Research">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Internationally recognised Norwegian scientists include the mathematicians
       <a href="/wiki/Niels_Henrik_Abel" title="Niels Henrik Abel">
        Niels Henrik Abel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sophus_Lie" title="Sophus Lie">
        Sophus Lie
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atle_Selberg" title="Atle Selberg">
        Atle Selberg
       </a>
       , physical chemist
       <a href="/wiki/Lars_Onsager" title="Lars Onsager">
        Lars Onsager
       </a>
       , physicist
       <a href="/wiki/Ivar_Giaever" title="Ivar Giaever">
        Ivar Giaever
       </a>
       , chemists
       <a href="/wiki/Odd_Hassel" title="Odd Hassel">
        Odd Hassel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Waage" title="Peter Waage">
        Peter Waage
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Cato_Maximilian_Guldberg" title="Cato Maximilian Guldberg">
        Cato Maximilian Guldberg
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 20th century, Norwegian academics have been pioneering in many
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_sciences" title="Social sciences">
        social sciences
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Criminology" title="Criminology">
        criminology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sociology" title="Sociology">
        sociology
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Peace_and_conflict_studies" title="Peace and conflict studies">
        peace and conflict studies
       </a>
       . Prominent academics include
       <a href="/wiki/Arne_N%C3%A6ss" title="Arne Næss">
        Arne Næss
       </a>
       , a philosopher and founder of
       <a href="/wiki/Deep_ecology" title="Deep ecology">
        deep ecology
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Johan_Galtung" title="Johan Galtung">
        Johan Galtung
       </a>
       , the founder of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peace_studies" title="Peace studies">
        peace studies
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Nils_Christie" title="Nils Christie">
        Nils Christie
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Mathiesen" title="Thomas Mathiesen">
        Thomas Mathiesen
       </a>
       , criminologists;
       <a href="/wiki/Fredrik_Barth" title="Fredrik Barth">
        Fredrik Barth
       </a>
       , a social anthropologist;
       <a href="/wiki/Vilhelm_Aubert" title="Vilhelm Aubert">
        Vilhelm Aubert
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Harriet_Holter" title="Harriet Holter">
        Harriet Holter
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Erik_Gr%C3%B8nseth" title="Erik Grønseth">
        Erik Grønseth
       </a>
       , sociologists;
       <a href="/wiki/Tove_Stang_Dahl" title="Tove Stang Dahl">
        Tove Stang Dahl
       </a>
       , a pioneer of women's law;
       <a href="/wiki/Stein_Rokkan" title="Stein Rokkan">
        Stein Rokkan
       </a>
       , a political scientist; and economists
       <a href="/wiki/Ragnar_Frisch" title="Ragnar Frisch">
        Ragnar Frisch
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Trygve_Haavelmo" title="Trygve Haavelmo">
        Trygve Haavelmo
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Finn_E._Kydland" title="Finn E. Kydland">
        Finn E. Kydland
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2014, the two Norwegian scientists
       <a href="/wiki/May-Britt_Moser" title="May-Britt Moser">
        May-Britt Moser
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Moser" title="Edvard Moser">
        Edvard Moser
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">
        Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
       </a>
       along with
       <a href="/wiki/John_O%27Keefe_(neuroscientist)" title="John O'Keefe (neuroscientist)">
        John O'Keefe
       </a>
       . They won the prize for their groundbreaking work identifying the cells that make up a positioning system in the human brain, our "in-built GPS".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
        Architecture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Architecture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Norway" title="Architecture of Norway">
        Architecture of Norway
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Urnesstavkirke.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="459" data-file-width="800" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Urnesstavkirke.jpg/330px-Urnesstavkirke.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Urnesstavkirke.jpg/495px-Urnesstavkirke.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Urnesstavkirke.jpg/660px-Urnesstavkirke.jpg 2x" width="330"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Urnesstavkirke.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Urnes_Stave_Church" title="Urnes Stave Church">
          Urnes Stave Church
         </a>
         has been listed by
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
          UNESCO
         </a>
         as a
         <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
          World Heritage Site
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With expansive forests, Norway has long had a tradition of building in wood. Many of today's most interesting new buildings are made of wood, reflecting the strong appeal that this material continues to hold for Norwegian designers and builders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1707" data-file-width="2560" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg/220px-Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg/330px-Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg/440px-Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dalen_Hotell_IMG_4773.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Dalen_Hotel" title="Dalen Hotel">
          Dalen Hotel
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Telemark" title="Telemark">
          Telemark
         </a>
         built in
         <a href="/wiki/Dragestil" title="Dragestil">
          Dragon Style
         </a>
         , a style of design architecture that originated during the
         <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_romantic_nationalism" title="Norwegian romantic nationalism">
          Norwegian romantic nationalism
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With Norway's conversion to Christianity some 1,000 years ago, churches were built. Stonework architecture was introduced from Europe for the most important structures, beginning with the construction of
       <a href="/wiki/Nidaros_Cathedral" title="Nidaros Cathedral">
        Nidaros Cathedral
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">
        Trondheim
       </a>
       . In the early
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       , wooden
       <a href="/wiki/Stave_church" title="Stave church">
        stave churches
       </a>
       were constructed throughout Norway. Some of them have survived; they represent Norway's most unusual contribution to architectural history. A fine example,
       <a href="/wiki/Urnes_Stave_Church" title="Urnes Stave Church">
        Urnes Stave Church
       </a>
       in inner
       <a href="/wiki/Sognefjord" title="Sognefjord">
        Sognefjord
       </a>
       , is on
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_List" title="World Heritage List">
        World Heritage List
       </a>
       . Another notable example of wooden architecture is the buildings at
       <a href="/wiki/Bryggen" title="Bryggen">
        Bryggen
       </a>
       Wharf in Bergen, also on the list for World Cultural Heritage sites, consisting of a row of tall, narrow wooden structures along the quayside.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hyttklokka.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="930" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Hyttklokka.jpg/220px-Hyttklokka.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Hyttklokka.jpg/330px-Hyttklokka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Hyttklokka.jpg/440px-Hyttklokka.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hyttklokka.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The 17th-century town of
         <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B8ros" title="Røros">
          Røros
         </a>
         , designated in 1980 as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, has narrow streets and wooden houses.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the 17th century, under the Danish monarchy, cities and villages such as
       <a href="/wiki/Kongsberg" title="Kongsberg">
        Kongsberg
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B8ros" title="Røros">
        Røros
       </a>
       were established. The city
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words">
          <span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too vague attribution or weasel words. (June 2016)">
           which?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       had a church built in the Baroque style. Traditional wooden buildings that were constructed in Røros have survived.
      </p>
      <p>
       After Norway's union with Denmark was dissolved in 1814, Oslo became the capital. The architect
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_Heinrich_Grosch" title="Christian Heinrich Grosch">
        Christian H. Grosch
       </a>
       designed the earliest parts of the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oslo" title="University of Oslo">
        University of Oslo
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Stock_Exchange" title="Oslo Stock Exchange">
        Oslo Stock Exchange
       </a>
       , and many other buildings and churches constructed in that early national period.
      </p>
      <p>
       At the beginning of the 20th century, the city of
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%85lesund" title="Ålesund">
        Ålesund
       </a>
       was rebuilt in the
       <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">
        Art Nouveau
       </a>
       style, influenced by styles of
       <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
        France
       </a>
       . The 1930s, when functionalism dominated, became a strong period for Norwegian architecture. It is only since the late 20th century that Norwegian architects have achieved international renown. One of the most striking modern buildings in Norway is the
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_Parliament_of_Norway" title="Sami Parliament of Norway">
        Sami Parliament
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Karasjok" title="Karasjok">
        Kárášjohka
       </a>
       , designed by
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Stein_Halvorson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Stein Halvorson (page does not exist)">
        Stein Halvorson
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Christian_Sundby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Christian Sundby (page does not exist)">
        Christian Sundby
       </a>
       . Its debating chamber, in timber, is an abstract version of a
       <i>
        lavvo,
       </i>
       the traditional tent used by the nomadic
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_people" title="Sami people">
        Sami people
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Art">
        Art
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Art">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_art" title="Norwegian art">
        Norwegian art
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5565" data-file-width="7783" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Adolph_Tidemand_%26_Hans_Gude_-_Bridal_Procession_on_the_Hardangerfjord_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          Brudeferd i Hardanger
         </i>
         by
         <a href="/wiki/Adolph_Tidemand" title="Adolph Tidemand">
          Adolph Tidemand
         </a>
         og
         <a href="/wiki/Hans_Gude" title="Hans Gude">
          Hans Gude
         </a>
         , 1848
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       For an extended period, the Norwegian art scene was dominated by artwork from Germany and Holland as well as by the influence of Copenhagen. It was in the 19th century that a truly Norwegian era began, first with portraits, later with impressive landscapes. Johan Christian Dahl (1788–1857), originally from the Dresden school, eventually returned to paint the landscapes of western Norway, defining Norwegian painting for the first time."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HFG_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HFG-233">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway's newly found independence from Denmark encouraged painters to develop their Norwegian identity, especially with landscape painting by artists such as
       <a href="/wiki/Kitty_Lange_Kielland" title="Kitty Lange Kielland">
        Kitty Kielland
       </a>
       , a female painter who studied under
       <a href="/wiki/Hans_Gude" title="Hans Gude">
        Hans Gude
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Harriet_Backer" title="Harriet Backer">
        Harriet Backer
       </a>
       , another pioneer among female artists, influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">
        impressionism
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Frits_Thaulow" title="Frits Thaulow">
        Frits Thaulow
       </a>
       , an impressionist, was influenced by the art scene in Paris as was
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_Krohg" title="Christian Krohg">
        Christian Krohg
       </a>
       , a realist painter, famous for his paintings of prostitutes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Of particular note is
       <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Munch" title="Edvard Munch">
        Edvard Munch
       </a>
       , a symbolist/expressionist painter who became world-famous for
       <a href="/wiki/The_Scream" title="The Scream">
        The Scream
       </a>
       which is said to represent the anxiety of modern man.
      </p>
      <p>
       Other artists of note include
       <a href="/wiki/Harald_Sohlberg" title="Harald Sohlberg">
        Harald Sohlberg
       </a>
       , a neo-romantic painter remembered for his paintings of
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B8ros" title="Røros">
        Røros
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Odd_Nerdrum" title="Odd Nerdrum">
        Odd Nerdrum
       </a>
       , a figurative painter who maintains that his work is not art, but
       <a href="/wiki/Kitsch" title="Kitsch">
        kitsch
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Cuisine">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_cuisine" title="Norwegian cuisine">
        Norwegian cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Category:Norwegian_cuisine" title="Category:Norwegian cuisine">
        Norway's culinary traditions
       </a>
       show the influence of long seafaring and farming traditions, with
       <a href="/wiki/Salmon" title="Salmon">
        salmon
       </a>
       (fresh and cured),
       <a href="/wiki/Herring" title="Herring">
        herring
       </a>
       (pickled or marinated),
       <a href="/wiki/Trout" title="Trout">
        trout
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cod" title="Cod">
        codfish
       </a>
       , and other seafood, balanced by cheeses (such as
       <a href="/wiki/Brunost" title="Brunost">
        brunost
       </a>
       ), dairy products, and breads (predominantly dark/darker).
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Lefse" title="Lefse">
        Lefse
       </a>
       is a Norwegian potato flatbread, usually topped with large amounts of butter and sugar, most common around Christmas. Some traditional Norwegian dishes include
       <a href="/wiki/Lutefisk" title="Lutefisk">
        lutefisk
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Smalahove" title="Smalahove">
        smalahove
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pinnekj%C3%B8tt" title="Pinnekjøtt">
        pinnekjøtt
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Raspeball" title="Raspeball">
        raspeball
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A5rik%C3%A5l" title="Fårikål">
        fårikål
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Sports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2100" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg/220px-Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg/330px-Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg/440px-Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bjorndalen-Trondheim09.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Biathlete
         <a href="/wiki/Ole_Einar_Bj%C3%B8rndalen" title="Ole Einar Bjørndalen">
          Ole Einar Bjørndalen
         </a>
         from Norway is the most successful Winter Olympian of all time, with 13 medals
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Sports are a central part of Norwegian culture, and popular sports include
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        Association football
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Biathlon" title="Biathlon">
        biathlon
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">
        cross-country skiing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">
        ski jumping
       </a>
       , and, to a lesser degree,
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">
        ice hockey
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">
        handball
       </a>
       . Norway was considered in 2017 to be the best per capita country in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        Association football
       </a>
       is the most popular sport in Norway in terms of active membership. In 2014-2015 polling, football ranked far behind
       <a href="/wiki/Biathlon" title="Biathlon">
        biathlon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">
        cross-country skiing
       </a>
       in terms of popularity as spectator sports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spopop_237-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Spopop-237">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">
        Ice hockey
       </a>
       is the biggest indoor sport.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorHall_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorHall-238">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Norway_women%27s_national_handball_team" title="Norway women's national handball team">
        women's handball national team
       </a>
       has won several titles, including two
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" title="Summer Olympics">
        Summer Olympics
       </a>
       championships (
       <a href="/wiki/Handball_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics" title="Handball at the 2008 Summer Olympics">
        2008
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Handball_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics" title="Handball at the 2012 Summer Olympics">
        2012
       </a>
       ), three
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="World Women's Handball Championship">
        World Championships
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/1999_World_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="1999 World Women's Handball Championship">
        1999
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2011_World_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2011 World Women's Handball Championship">
        2011
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2015_World_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2015 World Women's Handball Championship">
        2015
       </a>
       ), and six
       <a href="/wiki/European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="European Women's Handball Championship">
        European Championship
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/1998_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="1998 European Women's Handball Championship">
        1998
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2004_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2004 European Women's Handball Championship">
        2004
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2006_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2006 European Women's Handball Championship">
        2006
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2008_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2008 European Women's Handball Championship">
        2008
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2010_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2010 European Women's Handball Championship">
        2010
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2014_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2014 European Women's Handball Championship">
        2014
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Norway_national_football_team" title="Norway national football team">
        Norwegian national football team
       </a>
       has participated three times in the
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
        FIFA World Cup
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">
        1938
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">
        1994
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">
        1998
       </a>
       ), and once in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Football_Championship" title="UEFA European Football Championship">
        European Championship
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2000" title="UEFA Euro 2000">
        2000
       </a>
       ). The highest FIFA ranking Norway has achieved is 2nd, a position it has held twice, in 1993 and in 1995.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorRank_239-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NorRank-239">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">
        Chess
       </a>
       is also gaining popularity in Norway.
       <a href="/wiki/Magnus_Carlsen" title="Magnus Carlsen">
        Magnus Carlsen
       </a>
       is the current world champion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MagCham_240-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MagCham-240">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are about 10
       <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">
        Grandmasters
       </a>
       and 29
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Masters" title="International Masters">
        International Masters
       </a>
       in Norway.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Long_track_speed_skating" title="Long track speed skating">
        Speed skating
       </a>
       is a sport with great traditions in Norway. One of the highlights was when
       <a href="/wiki/Johann_Olav_Koss" title="Johann Olav Koss">
        Johann Olav Koss
       </a>
       captured three gold medals at the
       <a href="/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics" title="Speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics">
        home Olympics in 1994
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg/240px-Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg/360px-Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg/480px-Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg 2x" width="240"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Holmenkollbakken_in_background.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ski jumping hill
         <a href="/wiki/Holmenkollbakken" title="Holmenkollbakken">
          Holmenkollbakken
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
          Oslo
         </a>
         during the
         <a href="/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_2011" title="FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011">
          FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">
        Bandy
       </a>
       is a traditional sport in Norway and the country is one of the four founders of
       <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_International_Bandy" title="Federation of International Bandy">
        Federation of International Bandy
       </a>
       . In terms of licensed athletes, it is the second biggest winter sport in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of January 2018,
       <a href="/wiki/Norway_national_bandy_team" title="Norway national bandy team">
        the men's national team
       </a>
       has captured one silver and one bronze, while
       <a href="/wiki/Norway_women%27s_national_bandy_team" title="Norway women's national bandy team">
        the women's national team
       </a>
       has managed five bronzes at
       <a href="/wiki/Bandy#World_Championships" title="Bandy">
        the World Championships
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway first participated at the
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
        Olympic Games
       </a>
       in 1900, and has sent athletes to compete in every Games since then, except for the sparsely attended
       <a href="/wiki/1904_Summer_Olympics" title="1904 Summer Olympics">
        1904 Games
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">
        1980 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       when they participated in the
       <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics_boycott" title="1980 Summer Olympics boycott">
        American-led boycott
       </a>
       . Famous Norwegian winter sport athletes are, for instance, biathlete
       <a href="/wiki/Ole_Einar_Bj%C3%B8rndalen" title="Ole Einar Bjørndalen">
        Ole Einar Bjørndalen
       </a>
       and cross country skiers
       <a href="/wiki/Marit_Bj%C3%B8rgen" title="Marit Bjørgen">
        Marit Bjørgen
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rn_D%C3%A6hlie" title="Bjørn Dæhlie">
        Bjørn Dæhlie
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Norway has hosted the Games on two occasions:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/1952_Winter_Olympics" title="1952 Winter Olympics">
         1952 Winter Olympics
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
         Oslo
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics" title="1994 Winter Olympics">
         1994 Winter Olympics
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Lillehammer" title="Lillehammer">
         Lillehammer
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="International_rankings">
        International rankings
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">

        </span>

         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Notes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-12">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-12">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Svalbard_Treaty" title="Svalbard Treaty">
            Spitsbergen Treaty
           </a>
           (also known as the
           <a href="/wiki/Svalbard_Treaty" title="Svalbard Treaty">
            Svalbard Treaty
           </a>
           ) of 9 February 1920 recognises Norway's full and absolute sovereignty over the arctic archipelago of Spitsbergen (now called
           <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">
            Svalbard
           </a>
           ).
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Board1986_11-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Board1986-11">
             [11]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

          </cite>

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Human+Development+Report+2011&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fhdr.undp.org%2Fen%2Fmedia%2FHDR_2011_EN_Table1.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorway">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">

            ^

         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Wong, Curtis M. (14 December 2010).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/14/worlds-top-democratic-gov_n_796107.html#s206314title=Norway__1" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          .
          <i>

           .

        <li id="cite_note-104">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-104">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           Rapp, Ole Magnus (21 September 2015).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/Norge-utvider-Dronning-Maud-Land-helt-frem-til-Sydpolen-8168779.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Norge utvider Dronning Maud Land helt frem til Sydpolen"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Aftenposten
           </i>
           (in Norwegian). Oslo, Norway: Aftenposten
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             22 September
            </span>
            2015
           </span>
           .
           <q>
            …formålet med anneksjonen var å legge under seg det landet som til nå ligger herreløst og som ingen andre enn nordmenn har kartlagt og gransket. Norske myndigheter har derfor ikke motsatt seg at noen tolker det norske kravet slik at det går helt opp til og inkluderer polpunktet.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Aftenposten&amp;rft.atitle=Norge+utvider+Dronning+Maud+Land+helt+frem+til+Sydpolen&amp;rft.date=2015-09-21&amp;rft.aulast=Rapp&amp;rft.aufirst=Ole+Magnus&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aftenposten.no%2Fnyheter%2Firiks%2FNorge-utvider-Dronning-Maud-Land-helt-frem-til-Sydpolen-8168779.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorway">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-norway-105">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-norway_105-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-norway_105-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120126212439/http://www.norway.org/aboutnorway/society/political/judiciary/" rel="nofollow">
            "The Judiciary"
           </a>
           . Norway.org. 10 June 2009. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.norway.org/aboutnorway/society/political/judiciary/" rel="nofollow">

         <span class="reference-text">

           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141027221228/http://www.regjeringen.no/nn/dep/kud/dokument/proposisjonar-og-meldingar/stortingsmeldingar/2007-2008/stmeld-nr-35-2007-2008-/4/2/2.html?id=519980" rel="nofollow">
            "St.meld. nr. 35 (2007–2008) – Mål og meining"

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Logistics+Performance+Index&amp;rft.pub=The+World+Bank&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Flpi.worldbank.org&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorway">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Bibliography">
        Bibliography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Bibliography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book" id="Larsen">
         Larsen, Karen (1948).
         <i>
          A History of Norway
         </i>
         . Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Norway&amp;rft.place=Princeton%2C+New+Jersey&amp;rft.pub=Princeton+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1948&amp;rft.au=Larsen%2C+Karen&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorway">

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
               <div>
                <div class="plainlist">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    1
                   </sup>
                   <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                    Oceanic islands
                   </a>
                   within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    2
                   </sup>
                   Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>

                   <abbr style=";background-color:#B0C4DE;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none;" title="Edit this template">

                   </abbr>
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>

              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
               <div>
                <ol>
                 <li>
                  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China">
                   Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China
                  </a>
                  , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Officially the Republic of China, participates as "
                  <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">
                   Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu
                  </a>
                  ", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.
                 </li>
